column2: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The resettlement of more than 130,000 Indochinese refugees, which officials agree developed into the most difficult such resettlement in the nation's history, is drawing to a close. However, the related problems, and complaints continue.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. The last of the world-famous tuberculosis sanitariums in the Northern Adirondacks, the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital and Research Center, is closing down here in an atmosphere of disappointment and despair.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. The last of the world-famous tuberculosis sanitariums in the Northern Adirondacks, the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital and Research Center, is closing down here in an atmosphere of disappointment and despair.

The Consumers League of New Jersey, studying the effectiveness of the Small Claims Courts in the state, has issued a leaflet advising the public how people can act as their own lawyers in Small Claims Court.

New orders for machine tools in October ran 8.5 percent higher than in September but fell 29.1 percent behind the year-earlier level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend. October shipments trailed the September level by 1.2 percent but were 8.5 percent higher than in October 1974.

SANNOHE, Japan The maples are turning russet and the oaks yellow amid the green pines and firs on the mountainsides. The rice has been harvested and the straw stacked to look like the tents of an army camped across the valleys. The apples, red, pink, and green, hang heavy on their trees awaiting the pickers.

Anne Michelle Lang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Lang of Des Plains, Ill., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Thomas Joseph Paolino Jr., son of Associate Justice Paolino of the Rhode Island Supreme Court and Mrs. Paolino of Cranston, R.I.

Henry B. Goodfriend, who retired after having been a dealer in pearls and precious stones here for many years with Goodfriend Brothers, died Saturday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived at 176 Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.
What happens if the Internal Revenue Service issues a summons for your bank records?
Fred Hooper's Susan's Girl, a candidate for female horse of the year, will head a field of 14 today in the $60,000 added Berlo Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct.

FORT MONMOUTH, Nov. 23 A 39-year-old Army sergeant, suspected of armed robbery, and a 29-year-old military policeman were both in critical condition at a Long Branch hospital this afternoon after a gun battle during an attempted robbery outside a bank at the military post here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 President Ford proclaimed today a list of 2,724 products on which no import duties will be charged for 10 years if they come from 98 countries and 39 territories deemed "less developed."

TRENTON, Nov. 24 The New Jersey Housing Finance Agency completed a sale of a $65 million bond issue today, overcoming investment doubts and stiff market resistance generated by New York's financial crisis and the prospect of default.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his long-standing, wealthy friends and political supporters were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of mail fraud, bribery and "a pattern of racketeering activity."

Mozart is a composer of some quality, and Karl Kraber is a remarkable flutist. So, it naturally occurred to Mr. Kraber to round up all of Mozart's flute quartets and perform them on one program. The concert, on Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, was the first of three programs this season by the flutist and his associates.
The Westinghouse Electric Company's three outstanding debenture issues were downgraded in rating yesterday from AA to AA by Standard Poor's. The three issues total $450 million in face value.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Nov. 24 More than 1,000 mourners attended funeral services today for Raymond Koehler, a New York City fire captain who was killed last Thursday in a fire in Jamaica, Queens.

The International Ladies Garment Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, which a generation ago were split by personal and political differences, have entered a new period of friendship that has both of them thinking about an eventual merger of the powerful needle-trades unions.

The joint declaration of the French and Italian Communist parties that each would set its own strategy and seek power through the Western democratic system, independently of Moscow, apparently was designed to announce a common position for the projected allEuropean Communist summit conference.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 As Beirut's warring gangs slide into another mindless cycle of violence, the capital is passing, perceptibly, into a new stage of individual and social degradation.
These are hospitals with a difference: no ambulances, no night nurses, no meals. What really sets them apart, though, are the patients.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee, after long but unsuccessful efforts to decide the disputed New Hampshire Senate election, is sorting out an election battle involving a Senate seat from Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Republican fund-raising experts from all over the country met here today to try to inject some new vigor into the lagging campaign to raise money for President Ford's 1976 primary campaign.

To register or not to register. That's a question that holders of municipal coupon bonds frequently ask. To do so, some Wall Street experts warn, is to sacrifice marketability for the convenience and safety of reigstration.

What is going on in contemporary family life? In "The Making of the Modern Family," Edward Shorter, a young histrian of the "new social history" school, asks some very basic questions and explores some highly tentative answers. First of all, Professor Shorter wants to know, how can we really apprehend what has happened to the family in Western civilization: more specifically, how can we see beyond the familiar "court gossip" con- ...

TRENTON, Nov. 29 A highly controversial measure that would end the present primary system in New Jersey cleared the Legislature this evening after a feverish lobbying effort on the Assembly floor in its behalf by the Democratic state chairman, State Senator James P. Dugan of Hudson County. He said that he anticipated Governor Byrne's support for the measure.
Despite New York's fiscal crisis, two business organizations have decided to go ahead with plans requiring large new capital commitments in the city.

CARLISLE, Pa., Nov. 24 A potato farmer punished by his fundamentalist church for questioning its authority took that challenge into court here today in a complex, poignant case that could eventually test the limits of religious freedom.

A study group commissioned by the Twentieth Century Fund, in a report issued yesterday, urged financially troubled private colleges and universities to spend less of their endowment funds and to invest substantial portions of the funds in common stocks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 President Ford today expressed "complete confidence" in the United States representative at the United Nations, Daniel P. Moynihan, and White House officials said later that the controversial diplomat had agreed to remain at his post for the foreseeable future.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 Governor Carey announced tonight that the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature had "reached broad understandings" and were now optimistic that the $200 million New York City tax package, stalled here since last Friday, could pass both houses tomorrow.
The New York Jets did not draft defensive backs who were slower-witted than other teams' defensive backs.

DAVID CITY, Neb., Nov. 24 Basing his judgment on an opinion issued last week by Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court, a Nebraska judge partly maintained a gag order on the press today in a first-degree murder case here.

Dr. Henry Townley Heald, who as president of the Ford Foundation from 1956 to 1965 directed the distribution of $1.75 billion in the United States and abroad, died Sunday night of respiratory failure in Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old.

While friendship might been first, competition was a close second as the Chinese national women's basketball team defeated Queens College, 85-58, before a crowd of 7,029 last night at Madison Square Garden.

Robert S. Taplinger, president of the public relations concern of Rogers, Cowan Taplinger, a division of Rogers Cowan Inc., died of cancer Monday in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 223 East 49th Street.

NASHUA, N.H., Nov. 24 (AP) A man and his family, driven from their house by a swarm of bats, are back home today after a battle with the Government over whether they could use DDT to kill the invaders.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 24 (AP) Harold Solomon and Brian Gottfried each scored four-set victories today and set up an allAmerican men's singles final in the South African open tennis championships. They will meet tomorrow.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers Union, said today that he had learned that Volkswagen had decided "to go it alone" on any United States assembly plant.

A few hours after the beginning of Sunday night's inmate rebellion at the Men's House of Detention on Rikers Island, the City Commissioner of Correction, Benjamin J. Malcolm, and the chairman of the Board of Correction, Peter Tufo, crawled through the rubble of a teargassed prison shower room and poked their, heads through a large hole that had been knocked through the cinder block wall by inmates.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five of his long-standing, wealthy friends and political supporters were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of mail fraud, bribery and "a pattern of racketeering activity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today against the American Pharmaceutical Association and the Michigan state association, charging that their rules against advertising the prices of prescription drugs were illegal.

The three-year financial plan for the city ran into trouble on two separate fronts yesterday as major banks and the teachers union attached conditions to the purchasing or exchange ing city and Municipal Assistance Corporation securities.

The tunic is, of course, the newest top to wear over pants, but that's only the beginning. It's one of those fashions that sweep across the fashion board almost instantly these days, turning up in inexpensive sportswear geared to teen-agers and those not much older, as well as in the rarefied atmosphere of a Galanos or Norell collection.

Dale Houghton, professor emeritus and a distinguished scholar in marketing and sales at New York University and a pioneer in motivational research, died of cancer Sunday at the New York Infirmary. He was 82 years old and lived at 157 East 18th Street and had a farm in Ridley, Md.

Computers have always played a special role in detente. They embody an advanced technology which the United States is capable of exporting, and which the Soviet Union in particular is eager to acquire. Periodically in recent years United States Government approval for specific long-term computer export ventures has been presented as a trade-off for political concessions from Moscow.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 24 The jurors at the trial of Lynette Alice Fromme began deliberations late today after a Federal judge instructed them that they could find her guilty of assaulting, rather than attempting to assassinate, President Ford.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) An Agriculture Department specialist said in a sugar outlook report today that consumers were not receiving the full benefit of the declines in grower prices. The report added that for the first time in four years the world has a small sugar surplus and prices for ...
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 One of the world's top women pairs led into the final session of the life master women's pair championship here tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals.

Lola Vickers Seymour, wife of Whitney North Seymour Sr., a civic activist and a leader in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, died yesterday in Indianapolis. Mrs. Seymour, who was 74 years old, lived at 40 Fifth Avenue. She was on her way to a family Thanksgiving reunion in Crawfordsville, Ind.
Penn State won the Lambert Trophy for the 12th time and fifth year in a row yesterday, earning the Eastern collegiate football prize by a margin of 1 point on the ...

For the first time since 1967, the Health and Hospitals Corporation has renegotiated its affiliation contracts with the voluntary hospitals and medical schools that provide doctors for the municipal hospitals.

The 338,000 recipients of welfare checks in New York City will be asked to fill out new eligibility forms and return them in 10 days or face being dropped from the welfare rolls, city and state officials announced yesterday.

The International Ladies Garment Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, which a generation ago were split by personal and political differences, have entered a new period of friendship that has both of them thinking about an eventual merger of the powerful needle-trades unions.

ALBANY, Nov.24 Governor Carey announced tonight that the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature had "reached broad understandings" and were now optimistic that the $200 million New York City tax package, stalled here since last Friday, could pass both houses tomorrow.

ABOUT TIME Although Somerset Maugham's vintage play "Our Betters" is a recognized work of quality, it has a curious history and has virtually vanished, at least in this country. A sharp-edged comedy exposing the parasitic corruption of London Society, it first opened on Broadway in 1917, then tactfully opened at home after the war in 1923.
Implementation of the Sinai agreement and the ensuing disarray among the Arab states has given Israel an unanticipated breathing space.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 A highly controversial measure that would end the present primary system in New Jersey cleared the legislature this evening after a feverish lobbying effort on the Assembly floor in its behalf by the Democratic state chairman, State Senator James P. Dugan of Hudson County. He said that he anticipated Governor Byrne's support for the measure.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned today that "the United States cannot remain indifferent" to Soviet and Cuban military intervention in the civil war in Angola, adding that it could have consequences for East-West detente.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The White House said today that President Ford had ordered intelligence officials to answer questions about secret United States intervention in Chile's politics for the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, but only in closed session.

A mail truck carrying diamonds and other gems mailed by midtown jewel merchants was hijacked yesterday by a team of disguised thieves who fled with eight sacks loaded with the valuables, the police said.

MADRID, Nov. 24 The leader of Spain's Socialists said in an interview today that King Juan Carlos must "make clear his intentions for a democratic transformation within a month, or the pressures will mount inexorably against him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Soviet Union's newly planted 1976 winter grain crop is being plagued by the same dry weather that crippled this year's harvest and forced Moscow to buy huge quantities of United States wheat and corn, the Agriculture Department said today.

The 338,000 recipients of welfare checks in New York City will be asked to fill out new eligibility forms and return them in 10 days or face being dropped from the welfare rolls, city and state officials announced yesterday.
LISBON, Tuesday, Nov. 25 Several thousand farmers blocked the main highway to Lisbon about 40 miles north of here last night in a protest against the seizing of land by Communist-led groups.

Another corporate issue the General Motors Acceptance Corporation's latest financing fell several points yesterday as dealers lightened inventories preparatory to a heavy calendar of new offerings in December....
A Canadian couple, accused of having swindled more than $100,000 from insurance companies, were arraignd yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn on charges of mail fraud.

In his dissenting opinion in the Pentagon Papers case, Mr. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote that he shared the concern of a lower court judge that publication of the papers "could clearly result in great harm to the nation." That "harm" had been defined by the judge as "the death of soldiers, and destruction of alliances, the greatly increased difficulty of negotiation with our enemies, the inability of our diplomats to negotiate...."

Mamie E. Davis, a retired executive of the Young Women's Christian Association, who headed its Job Corps Extension Residence Program from 1968 to her retirement in 1973, died Sunday in West Side Adams Community Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 70 years old.

Litton Industries Inc., West Coast diversified industrial company, reported yesterday net income of $8.8 million, or 22 cents a share, for its first fiscal quarter, up 4.8 percent from $8.4 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 Lebanon's military and political situation took a sharp, turn for the worse today as fighting spread to wide sections of the capital and a high-level political conference broke up in argument.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 24 A Bronx man was convicted today of the 1974 slaying of a Yonkers policeman and became the first person in the state to face a mandatory death sentence under a law revised last year.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 A major brush fire burned out of control today in the rugged hills above Los Angeles, sending a dense orange pall over the city as strong shifting winds raised repeated threats to sections of the populous San Fernando Valley.

A 17-hour revolt at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island ended at 2:31 P.M. yesterday with the release of the last of five correction guards whom prisoners had held hostage but had not harmed.

WABC-TV, Channel 7 here, is really becoming big time. It had decided it needs two advertising agencies. So it has named Della Femina, Travisano Partners to promote its "Eyewitness News," its movies and its prime-time access programming, and Helene Mahoney Associates for "A.M. New York," children's programming and special projects.

A dozen or so of the nearly 2,000 inmates at the men's jail at Rikers Island are allowed to touch and embrace their visitors. The others are separated from their visiting friends and family by sealed windows, and they must communicate by telephone.

The stock market, which went into a minor slump last week over worries about New York's financial problems and too rapid growth in the money supply, became a little more cheerful yesterday as prices rose moderately.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 24 (UPI) Angry Thais burned the homes and shops of hundreds of Vietnamese refugees today in the aftermath of fighting between Thailand and Laos a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration ruled today that "restructured" potato chips those from dehydrated potatoes that come in uniform sizes may be called chips even though they are not made in the traditional manner.

Anatoly Karpov, unlike his two immediate predecessors, Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, has performed like a champion since he was awarded the world title in April.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company said yesterday it would increase nylon prices by 5 percent for apparel hosiery and upholstery fabrics and 6 to 8 percent on nylon and 210 denier Dacron polyester industrial yarns.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 Meeting in a lengthy caucus today, Senate Democrats reached tentative agreement on a $35 million emergency aid program for bus and rail subsidies, increases in public employee salaries and partial restoration of the state's Medicaid program.
Walter Bodenstein, whose appointment as group vice president of processing of Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., last week was severely criticized by many shareholders of the company, resigned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Nearly 50 Federal judges, at least seven of whom have apparently been under consideration for the vacant seat on the United States Supreme Court, dined tonight with President and Mrs. Ford.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday stayed planned staff layoffs at Goldwater Memorial Hospital, asserting that such a reduction could increase the number of deaths among chronically ill patients.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 As Beirut's warring gangs slide into another mindless cycle of violence, the capital is passing, perceptibly, into a new stage of individual and social degradation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Top Administration officials have begun conceding privately that American efforts to promote a new round of Syrian-Israeli negotiations have proved fruitless. They have now turned their attention to deciding what kind of international conference might at least provide a semblance of diplomatic progress next year.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in quiet trading as investors continued to be uncertain about progress toward solving New York's fiscal problems. Prices in the Over-the-counter market rose, however, in slow trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 After a $5.7 billion investment, the Defense Department is planning to shut down the Safeguard anti-ballistic-missile system, which from the start the academic and Congressional critics said would never work.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim conferred for several hours with top Israeli leaders here today amid reports that Syria was pressing for political con cessions in exchange for a renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peace-keeping force on the Golan Heights.

Clarence M. Dean, former associate director of the American Press Institute and for 10 years a member of the news staff of The New York Times, died Saturday in a fire in his apartment at 121 Madison Avenue. He was 64 years old.

Negotiations resumed last night in an effort to end the month-long strike by 1,400 elevator maintenance and repairmen as more and more breakdowns began to plague the more than 39,000 elevators they service in the New York metropolitan area.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) A person cannot file suit against libelous statements after one year has passed, because of the one-year statute of limitations, even though the libel was published because of negligence, the Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court ruled today.

An agreement was announced yesterday between the managements of Colt industries Inc. and Garlock Inc. whereby Colt's tender offer for all of Garlock's shares is being increased to $35 a share from $32 ...

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) A father saved his wife and three children by dropping them out of a second floor bedroom window today, but then died in a blaze that destroyed the family's home in nearby Plymouth Meeting.

When the New York Racing Association decided that a Saratoga Fair held in June would be a good way of making some money from its unused horse racing track it hired Grey Davis, the public relations arm of Grey Advertising, to promote it.

Lucy Jane Freeman Little, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Little 2d of Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas J. Tucker, son of the late John J. Tucker and the late D. Frances Guinand Tucker of White Plains.
Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, said yesterday that the American public now opposed Government intervention in the oil business, including price regulation.
MADRID, Nov. 24 King Juan Carlos I was urged by his exiled father today to establish a multiparty democracy in Spain.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Tuesday, Nov. 25 This South American territory became independent of the Netherlands just after midnight this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 An internal analysis in the Treasury Department has concluded that the troublesome figures on unemployment in October, and several other economic indicators, signal some slowing of the pace of advance in the economy in the current fourth quarter but not an "aborted" recovery.

SAN FRANCISCO Nov. 24 In the last three months, President Ford has lost ground among California Republicans to former Gov. Ronald Reagan, according to a study released today by Mervin D. Field, operator of the California Poll.
GENEVA, Nov. 24 (Reuters The number of working days lost in strikes in the non-Com munist world jumped by more than 35 percent last year, the International Labor Organization reported today.
KINSHASA, Zaire, Nov. 24 Zaire celebrated the 10th anniversary of the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko today.

The unsung connection is Carmen F. Zollo, a successful dealer in exotic leathers, who provided all the money $150,000 for the distribution rights to Ingmar Bergman's loving, Swedishmade movie of the Mozart opera.

Sears, Roebuck Company, the nation's largest merchandiser, reported yesterday a 12.6 percent increase in third fiscal quarter earnings on a sales gain of 4.2 percent. For the nine months ended Oct. 31, net income plummeted 28 percent from last year, with sales 2 percent higher.

The faculty of Columbia College voted yesterday to admit women as undergraduate students.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 The General Assembly's Social Committee approved today an international declaration against torture.

A small fire on a power rail forced the Long Island Rail Road to halt service into and out of Pennsylvania Station for 40 minutes during the rush period last night, delaying thousands of homebound commuters.

Dr. Edward Jacobs, a retired urologist who was on the staffs of the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Mount Sinai Hospital, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 308 East 79th Street.

The $200 million New York City tax package for which Governor Carey yesterday accepted "full responsibility" is, as the Governor warned the Legislature, a painful but essential choice the last hope for averting the "dreadful chaos" of a city default that now looms less than two weeks away.

Continued sharp price rises marked futures trading in grains and soybeans yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Some corn prices were up the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel and some soybean con-tracts rose thier 20-cent limit. Wheat futures were up almost their limit of 20 cents a bushel.

A Federal judge has moved to break the logjam that has delayed the adjudication of damage claims of tens of millions of dollars growing out of the March 1974 crash of a DC-10 jumbo jet in which 346 persons were killed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency proposed today that the United States, as a matter of "fundamental morality," should renounce the first use of nuclear weapons against cities.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The State Supreme Court indicated today that it would try to rule as soon as it could possibly before the end of the year on the constitutionality of the new state school-aid formula.

The American Basketball Association has applied for 50 playing dates each at Madison Square Garden and The Forum in Los Angeles for next season in a further battle for survival and recognition.

OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 24 (UPI) Toru Nakamura carded a four-under-par 68 today and won the individual competition in leading Japan to its second victory in the fifth $100,000 United States-Japan professional golf match.
For the third time in his 20-year-career in the National Football League, Earl Morrall is being asked to replace the starting quarterback and take the team to the playoffs.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 24 (AP) The United States has agreed to close Korat air base and pull out the 4,500 American servicemen and 50 aircraft stationed there by the end of February, the Thai and United States military commands announced today.
Brokerage houses earned $38.2 million during the third quarter of 1975 contrasted with a year-earlier loss of $34.1 million, New York Stock Exchange figures showed yesterday.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 24 Teachers here returned to their classrooms today, ending a 28day strike after ratifying an agreement early this morning. The walkout, which started Oct. 14, was the longest in the history of the state, outside of New York City.

HOUSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Terry Bradshaw's aerial artistry, powerful running by Franco Harris and Pittsburgh's Steel Curtain defense carried the Steelers to a 32-9 National Football League victory over the Houston Oilers tonight in the Astrodome.

It is hard to believe, but Zubin Mehta, has been conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic for 14 years. Hard to believe, for Mr. Mehta at least, from the viewpoint of one in the audience looks no older than when he took on the assignment in 1962, at the age of 26. So much for growing old gracefully.

MILAN, Italy, Nov. 24 (Reuters) Milan's public prosecutor, Guido Viola, has left for the United States to press for extradition of Michele Sindona, the Italian financier wanted here on fraudulent bankruptcy charges, justice sources said today.

Castle Cooke Inc. confirmed yesterday that it had informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that over a period of several years it had made "small payments to local functionaries" of some Latin-American Governments.
When Francisco Franco died he went to the New York Department of Motor Vehicles.

PRIOLO, Sicily, Nov. 24 (UPI) Workers cut through the blackened and twisted superstructure of the United States guided-missile cruiser Belknap today searching for three men believed crushed or burned to death during the ship's fiery collision with the American aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy.

KHABAROVSK, U.S.S.R The Soviet Far East, an area ranging from mosquito-ridden swamps to permanently frozen wastelands and encompassing the sprawling Pacific territories of the Soviet Union, is quietly shaking off long years of geographical and economic isolation.

Kennedy Center here and Milan's La scala would bypass New York and play only in Washington, it seemed as if the sky's cultural quadrant had fallen already.

The players of the American Basketball Association, worried by the contraction of job opportunities in their league and further losses, began legal action yesterday to help block a merger of the league with the National Basketball Association.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 24 (AP) Gene Mauch, a manager in the National League for 16 years, was hired today to manage the Minnesota Twins of the American League.

David M. Keiser, a retired sugar-industry executive and a leader in the city's musical life, died yesterday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) President Ford strongly endorsed Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger during his news conference tonight, declaring that "I certainly want him to stay on as long" as he wishes to stay. [Page 42, Question 20].

School Chancellor Irving Anker last night superseded Community School Board 24 in Queens and ordered it to comply with his directive to reduce pupil instruction time by 90 minutes a week.

Correction officers at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., failed to report to work yesterday in a protest. But at 1 A.M. today the State Department of Correctional Services announced the officers had agreed to return at 6 A.M.

Fred Lynn of the Boston Red Sox made history as a baseball prodigy yesterday when he became the first rookie to be voted the most valuable player in his league.

Steak Brew Inc., which operates a chain of 48 steakhouses in 10 Eastern Seaboard states, filed yesterday for an arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

Representatives from the cotton growing states are reported to be ready to stop backing financial aid for Cotton Inc., a federally aided promotion and research agency, mainly because its president, Duke Wooters Jr. receives a salary nearly double that of the Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz.

Governor Carey and Mayor Beame hailed President Ford's recommendation last night for a program of Federal loans to the city that, the Governor said, "represents a vindication of New York's case, of the merit of our position."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 An interfaith organization of religious educators met here this week to take a look at what some have described as America's "civil religion" that blending of patriotism and piety manifested when children sing a national hymn that invokes the name of God or a clergyman offers a prayer at the inauguration of the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 A surge in agricultural exports and a drop in the volume of imported oil combined to give the nation its ninth consecutive monthly trade surplus in October, the Government said today.
Prof. Hamden L. Forkner Sr., a former teacher specializing in business education, died at home here Tuesday. He was 78 years old and lived at 106 Morningside Drive.

In the art of the American painter Arthur G. Dove (1880-1946), the pastoral and the abstract are united with an uncommon intensity. A love of nature is combined with a passion for pictorial form that distills and celebrates, without literally describing, nature's most compelling visual attributes. It is an art that occupies two worlds, which the artist aspires to make into a single, organic whole.

GRAPESCAPE The opening today of an exhibition of drawings and watercolors of the vineyards of the Bordeaux region marks the first showing accorded an American artist, Wayne Ensrud, at the French Institute/Alliance Francaise (644-1820), 22 East 60th Street. WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The House voted today to create a Federal program to provide up to $50 million insurance for each art exhibition that is part of a United States cultural-exchange program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Congress returned to work to day almost certain to complete action, in the two or three weeks left in this session, on three major pieces of legislation that seem bound to put President Ford on the spot politically.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 The Assembly Judiciary Committee approved a Byrne administration bill today that establishes new standards for the release of inmates from the state's prisons.
OCEAN GROVE, Dec. 1 (UPI) A judge ruled today that this South Jersey shore hamlet could block the delivery of Sunday newspapers to preserve "the serenity of the Sabbath."
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 Westchester decided today to assume the major cost of improving its county road network, lifting an increasingly heavy burden from its municipalities.

ROME, Dec. 1 The heads of government of the nine Common Market countries struggled today with ways to overcome British demands for special treatment at the conference of industrialized and developing countries scheduled for next month.

Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx last night assailed the tentative decision to close Fordham Hospital as being based on "obviously superficial, inadequate and totally unacceptable" information.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 New Jersey rail commuters who travel to work within the state paid higher fares today with a minimum of grumbling as the State Legislature wrestled unsuccessfully with plans designed to roll back atleast a portion of the increase.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 Syria, opening another full-scale debate on the Middle East in the General Assembly, said today that the Security Council had made a "historic affirmation" last night by recognizing the right of the Palestine Liberation Organization to speak for the Palestinian people.

SAN FRANCISCO The San Francisco Bay Guardian, considered by many to be one of the country's best "alternative" newspapers, is having its ups and downs these days, and it is quite possible that the downs may put it out of business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department disagreed today on whether I.R.S. agents should spend their time on investigations that might not lead to tax-related charges.

LISBON, Dec. 1 "What we need now is some calm and discipline," Eduardo Moreira insisted today as he discussed last week's abortive military rebellion with visitors in his hillside home in the Lisbon suburb of Sao Mateus.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 The Assemby Judiciary Committee refused today to vote out a Democratic Congressional redistricting plan that was designed to create a predominantly white new district for Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. Democratic legislative leaders agreed afterward that this meant the plan was in all probability dead.

City officials have formally requested that the Tombs the Manhattan House of Detention for Men which was closed last year because of what were described as inhuman conditions, be reopened as soon as possible to house about 600 inmates.
Honeywell Inc. announced yesterday that its microswitch division was raising prices about 6 percent for list and contract prices covering its industrial and commercial lines.
Health Commissioner Dr. Lowell E. Bellin issued the following advice to those affected by the strike of private sanitation cartmen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The House of Representatives is expected to approve tomorrow President Ford's proposal to authorize $2.3 billion in shortterm loans for New York City.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The House voted today to create a Federal program to provide up to $50 million insurance for each art exhibition that is part of a United States cultural-exchange program.

The American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange have notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that they have uncovered irregularities in stock option trading, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 Amid the gilded surroundings of the venerable Breakers Hotel as the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers got under way today, one gets the feeling that things are looking up and it's not just the euphoria brought on by sparkling sunshine, warm weather and waving palm trees. There is optimism in the air.

Garbage and construction waste daily began piling up in the city yesterday on the first day of a strike by 1,700 drivers and helpers against 450 private carting companies. The carters ordinarily collect up to 8,000 tons a day from hotels, restaurants and other commercial establishments.
Inaugurating an international effort to probe the deepest layer of the oceanic crust, the drill ship Glomar Challenger left San Juan, P.R., yesterday headed for the mid-Atlantic.

City officials told the Board of Education yesterday that the $43 million it expected to save by deferring raises for teachers had already been accounted for in the city's financial plan and could not be credited to the board as part of the next round of budget cuts.
CAIRO, Dec. 1 The Egyptian Government today welcomed the Security Council decision to renew the mandate of the emergency force.

The Government of Kuwait signed an agreement yesterday with the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company for a take-over by Kuwait of the remaining 40 percent of the Kuwait Oil Company not previously owned by the Government.

The State Tax Department reported yesterday that revenues in all major categories for the first eight months of the state's fiscal year were substantially below estimates made when the budget was adopted last March.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 1 Arrest warrants were issued in Superior Court here and in Hartford this afternoon charging that the developer of a Bridgeport jai-alai fronton lied when he testified that he had given the late John M. Bailey $250,000 for help in securing a state gaming license.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) J. Edgar Hoover's secretary testified today that, following his orders, she destroyed his personal correspondence after the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation died.

ATAMBUA, Indonesian West Timor, Dec. 1 (Reuters) Indonesia promised today to support "quietly or openly" political parties in Portuguese Timor that want the territory to join Indonesia, and it said the solution to the issue now lay on the battlefield.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 1 (AP) Millions of dollars are being made and young forests throughout the West are being damaged in the increasingly lucrative racket of Christmas tree thefts, United States Forest Service officials say.

Leftover crisped shrimp with mustard fruits from the Four Seasons, and onion soup from the Brasserie were stored in large cans and refrigerated last night, at the end of the first day of a strike by private sanitation workers.

The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs warned consumers yesterday on the use of holiday scrip, or "holiday money," issued by some of the city's major department stores. The agency charged that the stores had failed to tell customers that if they did not return unused scrip they had obtained they would still be charged for it.

Stock prices declined a little yesterday, breaking off the five-day advance of last week. The Dow Jones industrial average, which showed a gain of 1.89 at 10:30 A.M., fell back to close at 856.34, down 4.33 from where it ended Friday.

Dodging the slings and arrows of suspicion automatically attracted by success, public television's. "Sesame Street" has raised about $5million for still another new season. The seventh season, which began yesterday, will add 130 hour-long, videotaped segments to the series designed for preschool children.

He raised his voice only once.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.
Other lovers of poetry on hand yesterday for a ribboncutting commemorating a Bicentennial salute to American poets agreed.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 In the wake of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's warnings against Soviet military involvement in the civil war in Angola, the Soviet Union has accused the United States of sending military men and weapons to the African country.

LOS ANGELES Vincente Saldivar, 135 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Randy Shields, 136, North Hollywood, Calif., 8 rounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The United States said today that it would participate in next month's United Nations Security Council debate on the Middle East along with the Palestine Liberation Organization but denied that this meant an end to the diplomatic boycott of the Palestinian group.

In the history of American modern dance, few have displayed social commitment as consistently as Anna Sokolow. From the 1930's, when she still danced with Martha Graham, but also created her anti-Fascist pieces, to the 1968 "Tribute" choreographed in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to her recent lyrical essays on love and the unloved, Miss Sokolow has held high the banner that says dance must express experienced emotion.

MIAMI, Dec. 1 (UPI) Earl Morrall, playing his 20th National Football League season, completed his first 13 passes for 123 yards and a touchdown tonight and directed the Miami Dolphins to a 20-7 victory over the New England Patriots.

Burger, the Court declined to review a case raising the issue of whether a private hospital that is largely Governmentfunded may refuse to let a doctor perform abortions there. Fragmentation has long been one of the most effective expressive devices available to the composer. In moments of emotion or stress, it is natural to find the phrase breaking down into words, the words breaking down into syllables and the musical line breaking down into short, disjunct notes. In our time, fragmentation has been carried to extraordinary lengths as composers searched for new modes of expression. Rather often, unintelligibility has been the predictable outcome.

In the fullness of time maybe the mixture of British folk-type music and the hardness of American rock 'n' roll will emerge as a real and basic part of rock history. The Army has selected the Picatinny Arsenal at Dover, N.J., as the site for the new headquarters of its Armament Development Center, several members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation said yesterday.

Four persons have been charged in the July 5 slaying of a haberdasher from the Bronx, including his wife and three others she is accused of having hired to kill him out of jealousy over "another woman," outhorities in Monmouth County, N.J., reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 1 As 860,000 government employees continued an illegal strike, Prime Minister Takeo Miki told a nationwide television audience this evening that "Japan's political system cannot really work if this severe confrontation goes on."

GROTON, Conn., Dec. 1 One of the longest, costliest and bitterest strikes in this state's history ended this morning in a cold blowing mist as the first contingent of 10,000 submarine builders trooped back to work under hastily erected signs that said: "We missed you."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1--The Palestine Liberation Organization today hailed last night's Security Council decision on the Middle East as "a triumph for the Palestinian cause over the schemes of the United States and Israel."
A strike that could have shut 200 laundries in the metropolitan New York area was averted yesterday morning when agreement was reached on a tentative three-year contract.

March world sugar contracts after testing the 13-cent level yesterday, which chartists have been watching, fell below the level. At the close of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the quote for March ranged from 12.75 to 12.78 cents a pound, compared with 13.13 cents on Friday.

Anna Roosevelt Halsted, the only daughter of President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday of cancer at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 69 years old and the wife of Dr. James A. Halsted, clinical professor of medicine at Albany Medical College.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Dec. 1 (AP) The organizers of a symposium to study photographs said to prove the existence of the Loch Ness monster backed out of the project tonight. They said "no useful or impartial discussion" could be held at this time because of recent publicity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 The Supreme Court refused today to review and thus left in effect a lower-court ruling that permitted a private but Government-funded hospital to forbit a doctor to perform abortions there.

Permission has been granted for Leonid V. Kantorovich, co-winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to go to Stockholm for the award ceremonies Dec. 10. The 63-yearold mathematical economist will leave Friday with his wife, Soviet officials said yesterday.

TRENTON, Dec. 2, (UPI) Opponents of intrastate fare increases on more than 30 bus and rail lines in New Jersey filed an appeal against the rises today, the fourth such appeal filed in five days.

Emeric Partos, the innovative fur designer who headed Bergdorf Goodman's fur salon for 20 years, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 70 years old and lived at 20 East 65th Street.

Six years ago three young men still in their 20's chipped in $3,500 each to buy a small apartment building on Thompson Street downtown. There were 35 apartments and the building needed major repairs. The buyers set about persuading the tenants to permit the upgrading and accept rent increases averaging about $25 a room a month. Not surprisingly, there was resistance.

The University of Arizona's 1975 John Peter Zenger Award has been won by Seymour M. Hersh of The New York Times for his articles on domestic surveillance by the Central Intelligence Agency and other investigative reporting.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 By a narrow vote, Canadian post office employees ended today a nationwide strike that had left the country without regular mail service for six weeks, at a cost of millions of dollars to businesses, charities and the strikers themselves.
The trade winds that carried the Moroccan fashion look to Paris recently have wafted across the Atlantic.

Once upon a time, a first-rate political cartoonist could be one of the most powerful men in the country. People loved him, courted him, envied him, feared him. Abraham Lincoln said in 1864 that the cartoonist Thomas Nast "has been our best recruiting sergeant."

Merce Cunningham and his Dance Company opened a week's series of his Events at the Roundabout Theater last night. Each Event will be different, and as they are numbered chronologically and individually by the company, they will run from Event No. 143 (last night) through Event No. 148 (next Sunday night).

Archie Griffin of Ohio State, one of the smallest athletes to win the annual Heisan Trophy as "the outstanding college football player in the United States," yesterday became the first man to be voted the award twice.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (AP) John Charles Meyer, a retired Air Force general who was a leading World War II flying ace in Europe and later commander of the Strategic Air Command, died today. He was 56 years old.
ROME, Dec. 2 For 250 million Western Europeans a uniform passport is to be issued beginning in 1978 as a symbol of unity of the European Common Market, leaders of the community decided here today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 3 (Reuters) The worst strike in Japanese labor history, a walkout by public workers that crippled the national railway system, was called off ahead of schedule today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The array of Federal "income assistance" programs from Social Security to food stamps will not grow much in the next 25 years as a share of the nation's total output of goods and services unless Congress and the Administration keep adding to benefits as they have done in the last 20 years, a Congressional Budget Office study concluded today.

The International Harvester Company ended its 1975 fiscal year with a loss of $40.9 million, its largest quarterly loss, after posting a record profit of $65.2 million in its opening quarter. The deficit reported yesterday is in contrast to a profit of $29 million, or $1.04 a share, reported in the fourth fiscal quarter of the previous year.

The wine book crop this Christmas bears some resemblance to the vintage in Bordeaux: smaller than last year but good quality. This time last year, publishers were elbowing one another aside in the rush to trumpet their latest wine book and a lot of silliness got into print.

The troubled Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, in Santa Barbara, Calif., has five new directors to strengthen its depleted board. They were elected Monday in Washington at a board meeting of the Fund for the Republic, the center's legal entity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The array of Federal "income assistance" programs from Social Security to food stamps will not grow much in the next 25 years as a share of the nation's total output of goods and services unless Congress and the Administration keep adding to benefits as they have done in the last 20 years, a Congressional Budget Office study concluded today.

CHICAGO After a delicious luncheon of goulash, sour cream, pate, crusty bread, butter, several wines and strudel had been devoured, the conversation turned to la cuisine minceur, or slimming cookery, which frowns upon cream, eggs, sugar and butter all in the name of pampering a gourmet's palate while stifling his waistline.
TRENTON Dec. 2 (UPI) The New Jersey Association on Correction today urged the Assembly to pass the Parole Act of 1975 before it adjourns for the Christmas holidays.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 There were no news conferences in Moscow today by legislators who wished to denounce the Soviet Government's proposed budget for next year.
NEWARK, Dec. (AP) The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company asked for a rate increase today that would raise basic home telephone bills about 20 percent.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market fell sharply yesterday in accelerated trading.
After four years of sitting empty, the Airlines Building across from Grand Central Terminal officially reopened yesterday, the old rows of ticket counters replaced by 48 boutiques.

A fast increasing number of air-traffic controllers are being backstopped by a new alert system that officials are confident would have averted the incident that brought two jumbo jets within 100 feet of a headon midair collision near Detroit last week.

Justice John M. Murtagh of State Supreme Court yesterday dismissed the perjury indictments against Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. of United States Customs Court and two lawyers, declaring that the evidence presented to a special grand jury was in "complete violation of the rules of evidence."

Elmer Love, a 6-foot-6-inch sophomore forward, scored 22 second-half points tonight, including Columbia's last 10, as the Lions posted an 83-77 victory over City College in their season opener at Levien Gym. Love had 27 points.

New York, the greatest manmade backdrop in the world, has always been a playground for moviemakers, and it was no accident that films made their start as big business here before moving on to greener Western pastures.

LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 2 (UPI) Wes Unsold and Elvin Hayes converted a pair of free throws each in the last 18 seconds tonight to give the Washington Bullets a 107-104 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

Just after 9:30 A.M. yesterday Muhammad Ali walked into the Hillside Aged Program Center in Washington Heights and told the director, Maria Brown, that he would like to provide enough money to keep the faltering program alive for at least a year.
The General Services Administration has released the names and model numbers of appliances that it found to be cheapest both in initial price and energy costs over the life of the product.
Economic planning is fast becoming the liberal utopian ideal of the 1970's.
Robert M. Deardorff, a freelance travel writer, died yesterday in Paris. He was 61 years old and lived in Rome.
TRENTON, Dec. 2 (AP) New Jersey's student loan program is weathering inflation, recession and defaults.
Three times in the last three weeks, Justice John M. Murtagh of State Supreme Court has dismissed indictments obtained by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, ...
Dr. Dorothy Houghton, a specialist in food chemistry and nutrition, died Monday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 74 years old and lived at Tarrytown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The House of Representatives voted 213 to 203 tonight to authorize up to $2.3 billion a year in short-term Federal loans to enable New York City to prevent a default.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Soviet Union, as a result of this year's harvest, has bought more than 13 million tons of grain from the United States and additional amounts from other countries. Further purchases are expected in light of today's economic disclosures in Moscow.
DOVER, Dec. 2 There were broad smiles on the faces of many Christmas shoppers at the bankrupt Dover Shopping Center here today now that they know the Picatinny Arsenal will remain open.
Archie Mason Griffin turned in three broken helmets to the Ohio State equipment manager during the recent football season.
John F. McCabe Jr., a management consultant, died Monday at Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. He was 64 years old and lived in Fair Haven, N.J.
Dr. E. Grace White, a marine biologist, died Monday in a nursing home near Chambersburg, Pa., where she lived. She was 85 years old.
TRENTON, (UPI) Dec. 2 A worker at the New Lisbon State School for retarded males told a legislative panel today of instances of roaches in food and mice droppings in the cottages at the institution.

Bill Campbell, who managed to double his victories in his second year as Columbia's football coach (from one to two) was rewarded yesterday with a new threeyear pact, which extends through June 30, 1979. His old contract still had 1 years to run.

PAST AND PRESENT Back in 1934, "The Scarlet Pimpernel," the first film derived from Baroness Orczy's novel of the French Revolution, had much to do with the continuing success of the pioneering British screen industry.
John F. McCabe Jr., a management consultant, died Monday at Sloan Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. He was 64 years old and lived in Fair Haven, N.J.

If New York City had any class it would start paying Catfish Hunter's salary without another day's delay. The Cat is one of the chief drawing cards the city is relying on to boost Yankee Stadium attendance to 2 million next summer and thus enable the taxpayers to get some return on their $75 million investment in the park.

Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York is introducing an experimental program to see if a second professional opinion to confirm the need for nonemergency surgery will eliminate unnecessary operations.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 2 (UPI) The dollar, which opened yesterday at seven-week highs, fell for the second consecutive day today on most European money markets, but London dealers said the dollar's undertone remained steady.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 2 Israel told the General Assembly today that it was prepared to enter into new negotiations on the Middle East "at any moment without any preconditions whatsoever."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Federal Election Commission ruled today that a member of Congress can accept regular payments for broadcast appearances without violating the statutory ceiling on honorariums that is designed to prevent bribes disguised as speaking fees.
Cancer specialists are finding increasing evidence that ingredients of the daily diet may be causing, directly or indirectly, half of all cancers among women and 30 percent of those among men.

Just after 9:30 A.M. yesterday Muhammad Ali walked into the Hillside Aged Program Center in Washington Heights and told the director, Maria Brown, that he would like to provide enough money to keep the faltering program alive for at least a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The United States announced today that it had formally proposed to the Soviet Union that they join in convening a preparatory meeting for a new Middle East peace conference at Geneva that could decide whether to invite the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 Harry S. Schwartz, chief economist of the Federal National Mortgage Association, said today that the nation's severely depressed housing industry had little chance of recovery until the country brought inflation under control.

MADRID, Dec. 2 Spain is reported to have begun a military withdrawal from the Spanish Sahara territory in an effort to avoid involvement in possible fighting between Moroccan troops and Algerian-backed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Supreme Court unanimously sustained today the Federal law that forbids the mailing of firearms that can be "concealed on the person." The decision rejected a lower appeals court's ruling that the law was so "vague" that it was unconstitutional.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 2 South African involvement in the civil war in neighboring Angola is being made increasingly clear in official and unofficial statements, and the situation has become a focus of national discussion.

If the first Joe Lapchick Memorial basketball tournament last weekend was any indication, the local college basketball season is going to be one of the best. That was the opinion of every coach who attended the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association luncheon yesterday at Leone's Restaurant.
Cancer specialists are finding increasing evidence that ingredients of the daily diet may be causing, directly or indirectly, half of all cancers among women and 30 percent of those among men.

CARBONDALE, Ill. For a variety of reasons, the coal mining community is a closed society. The working miner more or less eats and sleeps coal 24 hours a day. His friends are other coal miners, usually the same men he sees during his shift at work. His own well-being is tied to the well-being of the coal industry generally, and more specifically to the coal company he works for.

Kara Barlow, who stepped in successfully as Isolde to save a Metropolitan Opera performance of the Wagner work two seasons ago, did the same thing for the company's presentation of Richard Strauss's "Elektra" on Monday night. Danica Mastilovic, who had sung the title role in the work when it was given for the first time this fall, became ill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) Third-quarter earnings of the nation's railroads jumped into the profit column for the first time this year but still were 53 percent below the net figures for the same period in 1974, the Association of American Railroads said today. The association reported the railroad showed $115.2 million in "ordinary" net income for the third quarter.
Dr. E. Grace White, a marine biologist, died Monday in a nursing home near Chambersburg, Pa., where she lived. She was 85 years old.

Dr. Samuel Wilson Moore, who at his retirement in 1971 was professor of surgery at the Cornell University Medical College and attending surgeon at New York Hospital, the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital and the Lawrence Hospital in Mooresville, N.C., died Monday at the Sharon Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on Low Road in Sharon.

While many of the nation's active investors are studying their stock portfolios in an effort to find holdings that should be sold for tax reasons in the final weeks of the year, others are scanning the stock tables in the hopes of finding bargains.

Two effects that it had been hoped were mitigating the suspected effect of fluorocarbon spray can propellants on ozone in the stratosphere appear to be of little consequence, according to reports presented yesterday to a chemical congress in Mexico City.

Walt Frazier sat dejected in the dressing room last night, his right foot in a pan of ice water. The Knick captain had missed a deep jump shot from the left side that could have given his team a victory. Instead, the Boston Celtics won, 103-100, before a capacity crowd of 19,694 at Madison Square Garden.

Lawrence Hugh Riley, who wrote the Broadway stage success "Personal Appearance," a 1935 hit, died Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 32 Lockwood Road, Riverside, Conn.

THE HAGUE, Wednesday, Dec. 3 Five armed extremists who want independence for the South Molucca Islands in Indonesia seized a train in the north of the Netherlands yesterday, killing at least two men and taking about 50 hostages.

Continental Mortgage Investors, the nation's second largest real-estate investment trust, said yesterday in Boston that it was in default on $502.7 million of principal and interest under short-term domestic and Eurodollar credit agreements.
Gordon Duff, a retired television producer, died Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and a resident of Norwalk.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 4(AP)--Contract negotiations aimed at averting a nationwide rail strike continued early today as Federal mediators won promises by union leaders that they would not call a walkout as long as progress in the talks continued.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) --Congress was told today that the use of the Internal Revenue Service's extraordinary legal powers against organized crime was "very dangerous", and might pose constitutional questions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The State Department today described as "preposterous" the charge by Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had withheld information from President Ford about alleged Soviet violations of the 1972 agreements on strategic-arms limitations.
The American Society of Mechanical Enginers presented its Ralph Coats Roe Medal yesterday to Walter Sullvian, science editor of The New York Times, at the society's annual winter meeting in Houston.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- Manufacturer's inventories declined again in October but by the smallest amount since massive inventory liquidation began last March, the Commerce Department reported today.
BEILEN, the Netherlands, Thursday, Dec. 4--Eighteen more hostages escaped last night from a train held near here since Tuesday morning by five South Moluccan terrorists.

If air bombardment of population centers is Israel's only answer to the Palestinian problem, and terrorism the only answer of Arabs, then Arabs and Israelis-- and other peoples across the world--are in even greater danger of unending Middle East war than heretofore imagined.
What happens if you do not pay your Federal income tax when it is due?

Justice John M. Murtagh of State Supreme Court has ordered Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, to stop presenting evidence to a grand jury that was investigating Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco's role in a controversial 1963 Shubert estate settlement, court papers disclosed yesterday.

HONG KONG, Dec. 3--The abolition today of the six-century-old Laotian monarchy and of the country's coalition Government represent the culmination of a trend that began last May when Communist-led Pathet Lao forces moved into Vientiane, the capital, virtually without opposition and began installing their own officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--Did President Ford win or lose his battle of New York--a battle that his political staff thought could set some basic themes of the national campaign next ...

A Federal judge's ruling late yesterday again put off a scheduled strike of Staten Island Rapid Transit conductors and trainmen. The ruling, by Judge Mark A. Costantino, delayed the strike pending a "final determination" after a further court hearing Dec. 17.

"Man with a heart attack"--it was not an unusual call in the life of a Brooklyn ambulance driver. Jeffrey Wilson climbed into his red-and-white ambulance of the Long Island College Hospital when the call was relayed to him from the police 911 emergency network.

TRENTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)--Assemblyman S. Howard Woodson Jr., Democat of Mercer County and the first black in the nation to become a speaker of a lower house, announced today that hewould not seek the post in the new legislative session.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 3--James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed here today that the exchange would decide at a meeting of its directors in Detroit next Thursday whether Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith would be permitted to offer its customers small amounts of stock without having to pay an odd-lot commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Administration is preparing to announce soon the removal of the fee of $2 a barrel on imported crude oil that President Ford imposed earlier this year.

TRENTON, Dec. 3--The state's Natural Resource Council today unanimously denied a request for a riparian permit needed to construct 17 oil storage tanks on land bordering the Hudson River in a densely populated section of Hoboken and Weehawken.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP)--The 63-nation International Coffee Organization approved today a world coffee pact that for the first time included concern about the price of a cup of coffee to the consumer in times of shortage and high prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- Governor Carey said today that the New York Democratic organization would run uncommitted slates of delegates to the Democratic National Convention in all 39 Congressional districts in the state's April 6 primary.

Public esteem for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, always high in earlier days, has declined considerably in the last decade and particularly since 1970, the Gallup organization reported in its latest poll, issued yesterday.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 3-- An effort by the young president of Bennington College to prod her institution toward steps she considers necessary to insure its vitality has precipitated a crisis and clouded her once-bright future.
Earl L. Butz, the Secretary of Agriculture, warned yesterday that without remedial legislation before Dec. 31 he would be forced to impose "rather severe" production quotas on rice.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 3 (AP) --Wilf Paiement scored three goals, the first Kansas City Scout ever to do so, and led the Scouts to a 6-5 N.H.L. victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3-- The Lebanese Government today condemned the Israeli air attacks against Palestinian camps and Lebanese villages in the north and south of the country.

On Fridays, NBC-TV has had a very successful earlyevening line-up with "Sanford and Son" and "Chico and the Man." On Thursdays, it has failed miserably with "The Montefuscos" and "Fay." The daring solution for Thursdays? Grab the cooky cutter and punch out reasonable facsimiles of "Sanford and Son" and "Chico and the Man." Enter (to the sound of cynical snickering) "Grady" and "The Cop and the Kid."
Paul E. Welch, a magazine executive, died yesterday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.
Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said here last night that he was "increasingly attracted" to the idea of eliminating the "myriad so-called loopholes which now litter our tax code."
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 3 (AP) --New dates for the Second World Black and African Festival of Arts and Culture were announced yesterday.
PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 4 (AP) --A 14-hour drama in which two gunmen held 30 hostages in a Paris bank for $2 million ransom ended in a fierce street gunbattle early today.

YENAN, China--A quickening program of farm reconstruction is laying the foundation for the mechanization of China's age-old system of agriculture, and a propaganda campaign to rally support for the mechanization drive is under way across China.
Underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon Com pany won yesterday the Idaho Power Company's new one million common shares and reoffered them publicly at $26.75 a share.

DILI, Portuguese Timor, Dec. 3 (Reuters)--Three Indonesian warships shelled positions held by the Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor 50 miles from Dili, the capital today, Rogerio Lobato, defense minister of the self-proclaimed East Timor Republic, said here.

LONDON, Dec. 3--Irish and British authorities were locked in an angry dispute today over the case of Margaret McKearney, a 21-year-old Northern Irish woman described by Scotland Yard as "Britain's most wanted woman terrorist."
MIAMI, Dec. 3--Four small bombs exploded here tonight outside buildings that house Federal offices.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)-- Robert Mosbacher, a Houston businessman, was named today to heed fund-raising operations for President Ford's campaign for the Presidency in 1976.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Federal Bureau of Investigation supplied secret dossiers, conducted wiretaps and carried out physical surveillance for "political" purposes at the behest of all six Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Richard M. Nixon, the staff of a Senate committee charged today.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP)--The Chicago Bulls survived the Boston Celtics' fourth-period rally tonight and scored a 109-106 National Basketball Association victory.

About 350 guards at Rikers Island refused to take their posts yesterday for more than six hours in a protest against personnel cuts and inmate overcrowding, which they said had created exhausting and unsafe working conditions.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3--The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which recently notified a group of utility customers that it would terminate their uranium supply contracts after 1978, has canceled them already because the utilities have refused to agree to a uraniumrationing program to cover the three-year period.
Dr. James P. Hennessy, an obstetrician and gynecologist, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

LONDON, Dec. 3--Nigeria, flush with the oil revenues that make it black Africa's richest state, announced a $100 billion development program this year. Goals include new public buildings, army barracks and 12,000 miles of roads.

The city's Sanitation Department began the emergency removal last night of stacks of rubbish and garbage judged to be fire hazards in the worsening situation resulting from the three-day strike of private cartmen.

There was little talk of peace on earth at the "Pacem in Terris" convocation in Washington. Instead there was Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, charging that Soviet aid for the Marxist Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) was part of a Kremlin drive to "colonize" all of Africa.
Texaco Inc., the largest marketer of gasoline in the United States, cut yesterday the wholesale price of gasoline by 1 cent a gallon. The distributor price was reduced by 0.7 cent a gal lon.
The Cosmopolitan Club, an exclusive women's club, has been playing unhappy host to some very unwelcome guests recently--roaches.

ALBANY, DEC. 3--Last-minute snags delayed the expected passage today of legislation to enable the trustees of the five New York City employee pension funds to buy Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds, a purchase that must be partly completed by Friday morning if the city is to meet its payroll.
Prison sentences of 30 years were imposed yesterday on two convicted heroin dealers, with sentences ranging from eight to 25 years for four other participants in a major narcotics conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--President Ford's proposed legislation to provide up to $2.3 billion in renewable Federal loans over the next two and a half years to prevent a New York City default won its first Senate test this morning.

John Artis, who was convicted with Rubin (Hurricane) Carter of a triple-murder in New Jersey, said yesterday that a state legislator investigating the case had offered him a "deal" to free him from a life prison sentence, if he would admit that he had been an accomplice to the murder.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation has extended the deadline for exchange of $1.6 billion in publicly held city notes for 10-year M.A.C. bonds from Dec. 10 to Dec. 29, the corporation announced yesterday.

The business recovery that has been under way since the middle of 1975 will continue through 1976 but at a more moderate pace, according to E.F. Andrews, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) --The outgoing civilian and military intelligence directors denied today that there was a conspiracy to downgrade Communist troop strength in Vietnam before the 1968 Tet offensive.

J.P. Stevens Company, a major producer of textile products, reported yesterday a 30 percent increase in earnings for the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Nov. 1, on a sales gain of 2.8 percent. DETROIT, Dec. 3--United States new car sales were up 35 percent in November, the second straight month in the 1976 model year that deliveries topped the corresponding period last year, according to company reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI)--Six members of the Senate Judiciary Committee called for a full investigation into the health, tax returns, and former law practice of Judge John Paul Stevens, nominee to the Supreme Court.
Bernard S. Cooper, Eastern regional director of the accounting firm of Laventhol Horwath, died Tuesday at his home, 35 Seacoast Terrace, Coney Island, Brooklyn. He was 46 years old.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 3--The State Gaming Commission cleared the late John M. Bailey today of charges that he had accepted a $250,000 cash payment to help the developer of a Bridgeport jai-alai frontor to get a state license.

Douglas Williams, vice president of the brokerage firm of Wood, Walker/First Regional Securities, was elected president of the Community Service Society yesterday at the agency's 127th annual meeting.

VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 3 (UPI)--Bernadette Zurbriggen of Switzerland won a women's downhill race that opened the 1975-1976 World Cup and Olympic ski racing season today at Daille Mountain.

Peter R. Shaddick, former executive vice chairman of the Franklin National Bank, told a Federal judge yesterday that he would plead guilty to participating in a scheme that involved the loss of $30 million in foreign currency speculation.

The New York State Council on the Arts voted yesterday to give $961,000 in additional grants to 12 cultural institutions in the state with pressing financial problems. Nine of the institutions are in New York City, including six major ones: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Natural History, the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of Modern Art, the New York Botanical Garden and the New York Zoological Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- Congressional backers of a bill vetoed by the President that would give Federal funds to New York and other cities to repay them for protecting visiting foreign dignitaries said today that attempts to resurrect the measure would have to await Mr. Ford's return from the Far East.
Philip W.L. Cox, professor emeritus of education at New York University, died Friday in Clermont, Fla., where he lived. He was 92 years old.
The corporate bond market gave a favorable reception yesterday to a negotiated offering of $74 million in ship financing bonds as traders were awaiting the outcome today of a second- ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP)-- Blacks are apparently entering college in numbers roughly equivalent to their representation in the total population, but their dropout rate is significantly higher than that of whites, a Census Bureau study reported today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 4-- Japan's government workers' unions capitulated to the Government's firm stance yesterday and called off an illegal strike that had lasted eight days and brought the nation to the brink of a political crisis.
The first important winter watch of the season was "on" in upper New York State and New England last night. Ski-area operators were anticipating snow-making ...
