The New York Times and The Daily News warned the New York Pressmen's Union yesterday that the papers would take "appropriate action" if the union did not stop alleged work slowdowns that they said had delayed production and caused financial losses.
"Act of Aggression," the French melodrama that opened yesterday at two theaters, is so bad that it makes a film as vicious as "Death Wish" look good.
LISBON, Dec. 3--Portugal's ruling High Council of the Revolution met today for the first time since last week's aborted left-wing coup, while the crackdown on leftists continued.

GENEVA, Dec. 3--Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, warned the embattled Canadian organizers of the Summer Games, scheduled to start July 17 in Montreal, that they are expected to be ready to host the event as promised.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) --A bill to recapture more excess profits from defense, space and other Government contractors won 20-7 approval from the House Banking Committee today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) --The National Academy of Sciences said today it has urged Soviet officials to allow Andrei D. Sakharov to leave the country to accept the Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo, Norway.
The indictment of Albert H. Blumenthal, the Assembly majority leader, for perjury in the nursing-home investigation was reliably reported to be imminent last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- Pentagon officials are working on a multibillion-dollar BritishAmerican aircraft deal in which the United States would buy a British-developed fighter in return for a British purchase of some American radar-surveillance planes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a bill that would prohibit fishing by foreign fleets within 200 miles of the coasts of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) --The House Banking Committee unanimously approved legislation today to get some income for the Government from billions of Federal tax dollars kept temporarily in interestfree bank accounts.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3--The Soviet harvest, hit by severe drought conditions last summer, appears to have yielded as little as 137.2 million tons of grain, about a third less than planned, according to information in an official report delivered at the current session of the Supreme Soviet, or Parliament.
Nine superachievers in the municipal bureaucracy were honored yesterday for outstanding public service by the Fund for the City of New York.

Hoffa.

The adverse effect of last month's near-default by the city and unseasonally warm, rainy weather were cited yes terday by merchants as reasons for a relatively small gain, 3.5 percent, in November sales of New York's largest department stores from year-earlier levels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--A quarter century after Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were arrested as atomic spies, the Federal Bureau of Investigation today released 29,000 pages of investigative reports and other files that the Rosenberg's sons hope may reveal that their parents were innocent.
DEMAREST, Dec. 3--For the last year or so, Courtney Papatestas has owned and stabled a chestnut hunter named Merlin here at her home in this Northern Bergen County community.

BEILEN, the Netherlands, Dec. 3--In this flat farm region in the northeastern part of the Netherlands, militant youths dream of a homeland they have never seen--the South Molucca islands of Indonesia. Yesterday five of them seized a train near here and demanded independence for the islands.

ALBANY, Dec. 3--As his opening move in the taxation struggle with the Legislature, Governor Carey today had his aides prepare half a billion dollars worth of painful state budget cuts, including aid to localities.
LUBBOCK, Tex., Dec. 3 (AP) --Dr. William W. Frye, a specialist in tropical diseases, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3-- Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger again urged today that a wary approach be made toward the Soviet Union, which, he cautioned, views "detente as a continuation of confrontation in a different form."
LANDOVER, Md. Dec. 3 (UPI)--Jerry Korab's goal at 5:53 of the third period tonight enabled the Buffalo Sabres to salvage a 4-4 tie with the Washington Capitals in a National Hockey League game.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters)-- The Bank of England's 12month guarantee of $650 million borrowing by the Burmah Oil Company will be renewed for a further nine months from the end of 1975, Energy Secretary Tony Benn said in Parliament today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 3-- The City Council voted here today to kill a controversial plan to use 16 Rutgers University students as low paid city firemen in a plan to cut the city budget.

PEKING, Thursday, Dec. 4-- Chinese and American leaders have decided not to issue a joint communique when President Ford's visit to Peking ends tomorrow.
BOSTON, Dec. 3--A citizens group here initiiated today legislation to ban the possession of pistols by anyone but the police.

The stock market, in a decline that surprised even Wall Street's bears, fell sharply yesterday for the second day in a row. WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, who pulled out of the Presidential race a year ago because he was unwilling to undergo its rigors, introduced today a bill to create a regional primary system.

Two parallel escalators put into service two months ago as part of a $1 million refurbishing of the Columbus Circle subway station, partly as a convenience for outpatients at nearby Roosevelt Hospital, have been shut down much of the time, largely because of what the Transit Authority calls "mindless vandalism."
The credit markets eased yesterday in reaction to Federal Reserve moves to drain funds from the system. Prices in both the government and corporate sectors opened slightly higher...

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (Reuters) The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has said that under a proposed agreement submitted to United States District Court in New York, it would pay $5 million to settle all claims in lawsuits arising out of a 1966 offering of the Douglas Aircraft Company debentures and common stock.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 An unusual public debate has erupted here over the timing, wisdom and effectiveness of the Israeli air strikes against Lebanon on Tuesday.

A cluster of bird-lovers, some of them sobbing, gathered outside the Ethical Culture School at 33 Central Park West last night to mourn dozens of starlings, their feet mired in a chemical, that fell to their deaths from the school's roof.

Bergenfield, Dec. 4 While most New Jersey bus commuters will dig into their pockets for increased fares next week because of cutbacks in state subsidies, riders of the Red Tan Lines, owned and operated by the Rockland Coach Company of Bergenfield, will pay the same fare.

PEKING, Friday, Dec. 5 President Ford and Chinese leaders ended their talks here today after reaching an apparent understanding that their mutual interest lay in countering any expansion of Soviet influence in Western Europe, Angola and the Pacific.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 4 Joseph McGee wants the obituary writers to know that he does not wish to be remembered as the man who put diapers on the horses of Charleston.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 Elliot L. Richardson had an easy, clubby time today with the Senate Commerce Committee at his fifth confirmation hearing in less than six years.
The British Petroleum Company announced yesterday that its net income fell 66.8 percent in the third quarter to $77 million from $232 million in the comparable quarter last year.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (UPI) The Detroit Red Wings' general manager, Alex Delvecchio, discharged Doug Barkley tonight and immediately took over as coach of the National Hockey League team.

The city's public schools will begin charging tuition in February to 3,000 youngsters from other countries who are not permanent residents or who do not have immigration status, including the children of foreign businessmen working here.
The nation's money supply resumed growing at a fairly substantial rate in the latest statement week, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Carol Greitzer, who heads the City Council's Mass Transportation Committee, charged yesterday that the city's new subway cars were "unsafe, impractical and overly costly to maintain."

Every so often perhaps twice a year nowadays someone builds a new home in Forest Hills Gardens, that exclusive private enclave of mostly Tudor and Georgian conformity in central Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The staff of a Senate intelligence committee said today it had found that the United States had encouraged the overthrow of the "democratically elected" Chilean Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

A loner, without a cocktail date at a table or banquette, can place a foot on the reassuring bar rail, sip a Vodka martini ($2.60) and study Maxfield Parrish's large mural of an enthroned, quizzical Cole and some blithe courtiers.

It might have something to do with irrelevance and triviality, but that is not the point. "The Nutcracker" has been sold to us as a child's dream of Christmas and the perfect introduction to the mysteries of classic ballets. And why not? And, after that, why not?

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 Turkish Cypriot authorities have threatened to refuse to allow the United Nations Peace Force to continue operating in Turkish-controlled areas of the island.
John J. O'Connor, proctor at Dartmouth College for 11 years, died Saturday night in a Hanover, N.H., hospital. He was 54 years old.
Echoes of last month's rebellion at the House of Detention for Men are still reverberating on Rikers Island; the conditions underlying the explosion persist.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 A court determination on who will become the parents of many of the 2,000 Vietnamese children brought to the United States eight months ago has bogged down over a disagreement on a plan to trace the parents of the children in Vietnam.
Dr. Samuel Belkin, who retired as president of Yeshiva University recently because of illness, was invested last night as the first chancellor in the 90-year history of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 Officials in four Federal agencies either opposed or raised critical questions about a controversial nuclear energy plan that President Ford later recommended to Congress, according to documents obtained by the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 8 Four men who barricaded themselves in a London apartment Saturday were continuing to hold two people hostage last night. Police authorities suggested that the gunmen might be members of a group of Irish Republican Army terrorists who have been bombing targets in the city's West End for two months.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 the Coalition of Labor Union Women, at its second national convention, decisively defeated efforts led by women from the far left to change its basic structure and thrust and, instead, recommitted the organization to work for progress for women through the mainstream of the trade union movement.

A group within the Committee for Economic Development called yesterday for a temporary continuation of the personal income tax reduction that had been approved by Congress earlier this year. In a report entitled "The New Congressional Budget Process and the Economy," the program committee of the Committee for Economic Development also urged a permanent extension for the 10 per cent investmenttax credit.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund started its 64th annual appeal yesterday with $375,214.26 already donated by estates, trust funds and 198 contributors.

Reed, a high-ranking civilian in the Pentagon since 1973, to be Secretary of the Air Force. The 41year-old Californian would succeed John L. McLucas, named head of the Federal Aviation Administration last month.
Richard I. Brown, a New Jersey trucking executive, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 41 years old and lived at 17 Bennett Road, Teaneck, N.J.

The Monsanto Polymers and Petrochemicals Company, an operating subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, said yesterday that it planned to increase prices on all grades of butvar and formar resins by 10 cents a pound, effective Jan. 5. These resins are used in the adhesive coating, paper and textile industries.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 An attorney for six sports fans who say their health has been damaged by tobacco fumes in the Louisiana Superdome filed suit today to prohibit smoking and the sale of cigarettes in the stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it was trying to decide whether poinsettia plants and mistletoe sprigs sold for Christmas decorations should be labeled as possibly poisonous if eaten.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9--This year's harvest disaster, based on a grain yield seemingly as low as 137 million tons, has once again raised questions about the Soviet Union's ability to feed its people adequately.
Three gunmen held up a recently opened East Side bar last night and escaped with two rings valued by the owner at $175,000.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, second to Goodyear among the nation's largest tire producers, reported yesterday a continued decline in earnings of 12.4 percent for the fourth quarter and 12.8 percent for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

LONDON, Dec. 9 British universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, are losing so much money educating soaring numbers of foreign students that tuitions are likely to be raised or quotas set on admissions.
TRENTON, Dec. 9 The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to grant an injunction to halt the new fare increases for trains and buses affecting 700,000 commuters in the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has tentatively decided that flying the noisy Concorde supersonic jet aircraft into New York city is undesirable and that flying it into Washington is questionable.

Brian Winters, the kid who grew up in New York as a Knick rooter, helped the Milwaukee Bucks beat them last night, 109-100, at Madison Square Garden.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 9 A two-day meeting of player representatives of the 24 major league baseball teams will start at the Americana Hotel here tomorrow, to be devoted mainly to defining positions and devising strategy for the general labor agreement that has to be negotiated in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he had put off until next month a visit to Moscow designed to seek a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations on limiting strategic arms.

Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Post have voted 168 to 9 to authorize a strike if they are unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract, Harry Fisdell, executive vice president of the New York Guild, announced yesterday.

For the seventh week in succession the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City remained virtually unchanged last week, dropping 0.1 per cent, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 9 They were sitting around a tiny horseshoe-shaped bar in a former locksmith's shop in the Cite Berryer, an 18th-century shopping arcade near the Place de la Madeleine.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 9 Soviet warships are using Nigeria's ports, and a number of MIG-21J fighter-bombers have been delivered to the politically and economically important West African state, according to a report prepared by intelligence officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Restructuring the local property tax could encourage development in Jersey City and even enable the city to drop its "temporary" one-year payroll tax without losing revenue, according to a report released yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 The Public Service Commission reported today two different values for the costs and earnings of the power facilities in the upstate town of Massena, which has voted to take over and operate the plant of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The use of aerosol-dispensed hairsprays, antiperspirants and deodorants in the United States accounts for nearly half the world's air pollution by fluorocarbons, which may be dangerously depleting the upper atmosphere's protective layer of ozone according to a report released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Gulf Oil Corporation's Texas lobbyist has testified that he has donated thousands of dollars to candidates for state office since 1960.

Willard Klose, a retired advertising executive, died Sunday at his home, Echo Valley Farm, Red Hook, N.Y. He was 65 years old.
TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Despite unemployment exceeding 13 percent, New Jersey's economy improved during October, the State Department of Labor and Industry has reported.

The 64th annual Christmas appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund heard from 21 contributors who gave $702.76, to bring the fund's over-all total to $384,868,02.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 Reuters)--Young orthodox Jews trying to build an unauthorized village near Nablus in the occupied West Bank today moved to a nearby army camp under a compromise worked out with Defense Minister Shimon Peres.
The owners of 91 private nursing homes in the city called upon Governor Carey yesterday to intervene to avert a strike threatened for 7 A.M. tomorrow by their nurses and other employees.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 9 Israel today expressed its official "satisfaction" with the United States veto last night of a resolution in the Security Council, but Israeli officials said privately that "important differences" still separated Washington and Jerusalem on how to deal with the Palestinian issue.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 Vice President Rockefeller said today that the financial package developed to save New York City from default could collapse unless Congress acted within two weeks to approve a Federal revenue-sharing program.

LISBON, Dec. 9--Portugal's Foreign Minister said today that while the Communist Party had some "moral responsibility" for the unsuccessful left-wing military uprising two weeks ago, the party was "indispensible" to the advance of the Portuguese revolution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) The State Department said today that it expected to reach agreement soon with the Soviet Union on freight rates for American grain shipments to the Soviet Union and on importing cheap Soviet oil into the United States.

A 66-year-old man who bolted from his car on a residential street in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn to chase a mugger, collapsed and died of a heart attack yesterday after running after the assailant.
"The Enchanted World of Dolls," a Christmas display of more than 200 dolls, doll houses and miniature rooms from 50 countries, opened at the World Trade Center yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 Clarence N. Medlin, an escaped convict who disappeared last Friday in Florida, reportedly with $9,000 paid by CBS News for information he stated he had on the location of the body of James R. Hoffa, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 Racially tense South Boston High School began its first day under court supervision with fist fights today, and a fire bomb was thrown into the office of a black civil rights group.
Clara Kent Pearce, daughter of Rockwell Kent, the artist, died Monday at her home in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 62 years old.
PEKING, Dec. 10 (Reuters) A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed today that last year's grain harvest was 274.9 million metric tons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The Senate, in pro forma actions today, appropriated $2.3 billion in funds for seasonal loans to avert a New York City default and approved a revised Municipal Bankruptcy Law to ease the city's ability to petition for bankruptcy.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 On Jan. 10, 1974, Center Stage, Baltimore's resident theater, burned down. Last night the company opened the doors of its new $1.7 million theater with a production of "Tartuffe." The rebirth of Center Stage in downtown Baltimore is a major artistic event for Maryland and also for the American theater. It shows what community enterprise can do to revitalize the inner city, how art can collaborate with urban renewal.

The FMC Corporation announced yesterday that its film and packaging division was raising prices of cellophane packaging films about 8 percent on average, effective Jan. 19. The increases are up to 13 cents a pound depending on the cellophane type and yield.

A "catastrophic illness" health insurance plan being proposed by the State Standing Committee on Health was roundly denounced by most witnesses testifying yesterday at a public hearing to get public opinion on the proposed plan.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 The wife of Andrei D. Sakharov accepted his Nobel Peace Prize here today, reading a message from him saying he shared the honor with "all prisoners of conscience in the Soviet Union and in other Eastern European countries as well as with those who fight for their liberation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10?The Commerce Department reported today that retail sales rose by more than $500 million in November, and sales for both September and October have been revised upward, indicating a distinctly stronger tone for consumer spending than had been conveyed by earlier estimates for those months.

OTTAWA, Dec. 10 (Reuters) The Anti-Inflation Board of Canada has ruled that a proposed contract that ended a six-week national postal strike last week violated the Government's wage and price control program, official sources said today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 10 Prime minister Yitzhak Rabin threatened at a party caucus here last night to resign in a move described by his aides today as more of a challenge to his critics to come up with alternative proposals than a serious intention to give up his office.
Grain and soybean prices held relatively steady yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Russel A. Plimpton, former director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

Moynihan, the chief American delegate, but the debate in the General Assembly ended in a tactical defeat of sorts for the Russians and their allies.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to accept a $2.87 million Federal grant that will permit the Fire Department to rehire 101 laid-off firemen in addition to 150 who will return on Monday.
TRENTON, Dec. 10 Governor Byrne won a crucial political victory today, with the struggle for control of the Democratic majority leadership of the State Senate apparently resolved in his favor.

Humphrey should be looked upon as a pair of Harold Stassens, showing up at conventions and an occasional fund-raising event, deferred to out of respect for age and an ability to cheat absolute political death. WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) F.B.I. investigators gave Judge John Paul Stevens, nominee to the Supreme Court, a "highly commendatory" rating today, and the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said the Senate may vote on the confirmation before Congress adjourns Dec. 19.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Glenn McDonald singlehandedly stopped a Milwaukee comeback early in the fourth period and the Boston Celtics then routed the Bucks, 111-98, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which supplies 80 percent of the nation's telephone services, plans to increase construction expenditures by $500 million next year, to $10 billion, John D. deButts, chairman of the company, said here yesterday. Despite the rise, Mr. deButts said, an increase in internally generated funds will probably enable the company to seek no more new capital next year beyond the $2.9 billion sought this year.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled yesterday that the Emergency Financial Control Board had the legal right "to review, control and supervise the formal management of the city," including the right of final review of contracts approved by the Board of Estimate.

TRENTON, Dec. 10, (AP) Governor Byrne expressed concern over the possible costs and inconveniences of a proposed law to require photographs on driver's licenses at a public hearing he conducted today on the measure. The legislation has cleared both the Senate and Assembly and is now before the Governor.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) The father of a 5-month-old girl who died after being refused admission to two hospitals accused British hospital doctors today of "playing God with human lives" by conducting their work slowdown.

SMOOTH HARMONY The keyboard music of Len Berge adds to the pleasantry of a new restaurant called Prive (688-8778), at 1078. First Avenue (between 58th and 59th Streets). This is a convenient drop-in spot around cocktail time or later, with cheerful lighting, beige walls and a subdued decor of the 1930's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) Negotiations have broken off indefinitely between United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, and representatives of a striking machinist union, the National Mediation Board said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Common Cause said today that 100 members of the House who "voted on the side of the real-estate industry" on a recent tax bill amendment received a total of $100,000 from the industry's political arm last year.

NEWARK, Dec. 10 (AP) Beginning Jan. 1, couples who wish to have Roman Catholic marriage services in New Jersey will be required to attend classes on the physical, emotional and religious aspects of marriage.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 Ralph Guy, the United States Attorney here, said at a news conference today that there were no indictments expected in the Hoffa case in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The House Select Committee on Intelligence today withdrew its recommendation that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger be held in contempt of Congress for failing to provide the committee with subpoenaed documents.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrests today of two men on charges stemming from the abduction six days ago or James J. Crawford, an assistant bank manager in Detroit. Police sources said a third man also was detained.

APRICA, Italy, Dec. 10 (AP) Brigitte Totschnig won a women's downhill ski race today and took the lead for the 1976 World Cup, restoring the shaken prestige of the Austrian team after the retirement of the fivetime champion, AnneMarie Proell.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 10 (AP) Indonesia has suspended trade talks with the Netherlands, apparently because the Dutch Government has been unable to end the occupation of the Indonesian Consulate in Amsterdam by South Moluccan nationalists, the Dutch Economics Ministry announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The House Select Committee on Intelligence today withdrew its recommendation that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger be held in contempt of Congress for failing to provide the committee with subpoenaed documents.

Assemblyman Eldridge Hawkins, a Democrat of Essex County, turned over a final report on his investigation of the Carter-Artis triple-murder conviction in New Jersey to Governor Byrne yesterday.

Jerry Courville, a soft-spoken, 40-year-old steel salesman who has won more than 50 golf tournaments in and near the metropolitan area, received the Distinguished Service Award of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at its annual meeting at the Biltmore.

Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York usually devote themselves to resuscitations of complete full-length operas in their Carnegie Hall concerts, but on Tuesday night they presented a mixed bag of shorter works and excerpts.

Gene Moore's life is an ode to taste. He has spent the better part of his life creating windows on Fifth Avenue, the last 20 years for Tiffany Co.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 Governor Carey journeyed to Washington today to confer with Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, but came away no closer to a solution that would avert a default of the State Housing Finance Agency on Monday.
HARTFORD, Dec. 10 A 31year-old Connecticut man was charged today with two longunsolved murders of young women, one in this state and one in New York.

City marshals accused of misconduct will face disciplinary hearings by the city's Investigation Department and if convicted can be suspended for up to six months, under an order yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

The Bowmar Instrument Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $25.5 million for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 after including $265,000 earned from continuing operations. The House Commerce Committee set the stage yesterday for a possible compromise with the Ford Administration on a sweeping bill to reorganize the seven bankrupt Northeast railroads and aid other troubled carriers around the nation.

He hired the the owner of the office to prepare his returns and received his "instant" refund. Conditions for businesses that operate offices in New York will continue to deteriorate in the next 10 years and this will force more corrorate headquarters and more office jobs out of the city, according to a new study published yesterday by a leading firm of relocation consultants.

Wallace's direct-mail fundraising campaign, told the Privacy Protection, Study Commission today that any restriction on the use of mailing lists would "restrict free speech" and severely hamper fund raising for causes and candidates of all persuasions.
WASHINGON, Dec. 10 The Defense Department notified Congress today of plans to sell Israel 25 F-15 jet fighters, the most advanced interceptor in the Air Force inventory, for $600 million.

The camera is not afraid to linger on the musician struggling and triumphantly succeeding with his art. WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) Twelve states asked the Federal District Court today to block the $2.4 billion postal rate increase scheduled to take effect Dec. 28.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Bernard Bergman of defrauding a chain of nursing homes and of filing false reports to stockholders.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Pepsico Inc., said today it had signed an agreement with the Soviet Union to double the production of Pepsi-Cola in the Soviet Union with a second plant to be Guilt by next summer on the Black Sea coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) A judge for the Environmental Protection Agency ruled today that the agency should drop its attempt to ban most uses of two widely sold pesticides, heptachlor and chlordane, on the ground that their cancer-causing potential had not been proved.

The Republican leaders of the State Legislature, in the first sign of movement away from their public position that tax increases are "not a subject for negotiaton," agreed yesterday to discuss the issue with representatives of the Governor's office and the legislative Democrats.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (UPI) The type of spray can gases that scientists fear may be endangering the earth's ozone radiation shield have more than doubled in the stratosphere over New Mexico since 1968, a researcher at the University of Denver reported today.

If the snafu over the city's new Firemen's Training Center is a reliable indicator, official business is proceeding as usual in New York. Completed, controversial, and to date unoccupied, the new complex on Ward's Island seems to be a standard case of city operating procedure: a battle of bureaucracies a failure of communication, and the inability to cope with anything that breaks the mold of familiar practice.

Fed up with crime and violence on prime-time television and radio and disheartened at the relegation of religious broadcasting to other than prime-time hours, a group of churches, religious organizations and individuals in the metropolitan area have banded together to try to remedy the situation.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12? An offshore oil rig about the size of the Empire State Building will be built to produce oil and natural gas from a major new undersea discovery near the mouth of the Mississippi River, the Shell Oil Company announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Dec. 13 Moslem and leftist gunmen poured heavy fire through the day yesterday into a burning luxury hotel that was the last major position of Christian gunmen in downtown Beirut.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 12 (UPI) Peru and the United States announced today a provisional agreement in their negotiations over compensation for the nationalized iron ore properties of the Marcona Mining Company.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12 President Luis Echeverria Alvarez assured representatives of major American Jewish organizations today that his Government "in no way identified Zionism with racism" despite its vote to that effect at the United Nations last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, was ordered today to stand trial on charges of violating Federal campaign law after a United States District Court Judge nullifled his guilty plea.

"Hey, I'm going home," Willie Logan said over and over again yesterday. The 10-yearold boy whom nobody had wanted, and who lived for two years at Bellevue Hospital because he had no other home, was leaving with his new mother, Florence Logan.
NEWARK, Dec. 12 (AP) John G. Morello, a Newark mounted patrolman, has been acquitted of a murder charge in the death of a Hispanic man during the city's 1974 Labor Day disturbances.
The question of whether the present zoning for high schools on Staten Island should be maintained was argued at a preliminary hearing yesterday.

Annette Simpson, a dress designer responsible over the years for a number of fashion innovations, died Thursday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital. She was 83 years old and formerly had lived at 10 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) Mitchell Kobelinski, President Ford's nominee to head the Small Business Administration, was an officer of a bank that became involved in "highly improper" bank transactions, the Better Goverment Association says.

Sam Shepard's "Geography of a Horse Dreamer," which was first staged in 1974 at tha Yale Repertory Theater, is now, playing at the Manhattan Theater Club. The production is entirely different, but the point of the play is basically the same. The theme is the corruption of innocence by civilization, the perversion of an American dream.
Plans were announced yesterday for auctioning one of five municipal cemeteries, the 12-acre Canarsie Cemetery in Brooklyn, with the proceeds to be credited to the city's general fund.

About halfway through the Washington Redskins' season, their rookie running back, Mike Thomas, was startled to hear Chris Hanburger, the 34-year-old linebacker, talking to him.
For the second session in a row prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed while those in the over-thecounter market closed lower.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12--Legislation repealing the so-called "fair trade" laws, which for nearly 40 years have permitted price-fixing on many consumer products, was signed today by President Ford.

The Jets left yesterday for San Diego, and that made the Chargers very happy. In fact, most teams smile a bit more when they know the New Yorkers are coming to town.

The Honda Motor Company of Tokyo announced yesterday that its United States subsidiary, the American Honda Motor Company, had raised suggested retail prices of passenger cars by an average of 3 percent on 1976 model vehicles. The price increase was prompted by an improvement in the new models' drivability, the company said. The price of the 1,500-cubic-centimeter, twodoor "Civic" passenger model is $2,979, up from $2,879, according to the announcement.

Alfred A. Giardino, the chairman of the Board of Higher Education, has told Mayor Beame that he will not be available for reappointment to the board when his current term expires on Dec. 31.

The negotiating committee of the Newspaper Guild last night set a strike deadline at The New York Post for 6 A.M. next Thursday, according to Harry Fisdell, the union's executive vice president.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 12 Voters in this essentially conservative Canadian province have restored the conservative Social Credit Party to power with a commanding margin, ending more than three years of Socialist rule.

Aaron Copland enjoys telling how his 'Appalachian Spring" was named by Martha Graham, without consulting him, after he composed the ballet score for her. For all one knows, "Appalachian Spring" actually depicts the changing moods of street life in Mr. Copland's native Brooklyn.

"Camera Three," the venerable and always laudable CBS series that is slipped into the schedule on Sundays at 11 A.M., is devoting its next two half hours to Ryszard Cieslak and a physical demonstration called "The Body Speaks." In addition to being the company's leading actor, he is the closest collaborator of Jerzy Grotowski, director of the highly experimental, avant garde group.

Leo Camarillo roared down Interstate 35 toward Oklahoma City and the National Finals Rodeo, towing his roping horse, Super Stick, in a trailer. For Leo Camarillo, the 17th stampede represented the impossible dream because, although his specialty is the team roping event, he was leading the world for the all-around championship.

Judge Herbert Russell Morss Jr. of Vermont District Court died Saturday in a one-car accident in Royalton, Vt. He was 65 years old and lived in Chelsea, Vt.

Australia's voters have followed those of New Zealand by swinging dramatically to the right, giving the Liberal and Country Party coalition its biggest victory in the history of the Federation. In each case, a Labor Party that had governed for only three years was turned out decisively so emphatically in Australia as to raise doubts about the party's survival.

Eastern European countries have run up a debt in the West of some $32 billion, up by $7 billion to $9 billion from the end of 1974, financial analysts here estimate. NEWARK, Dec. 15 (AP) Nine months ago, Claudius Giesick admitted killing his wife, Patricia, to collect $250,000 in insurance on her life. He got a 21-year jail term.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 President Ford gave his tacit approval today to a sharp attack made by his campaign manager this weekend on Ronald Reagan, who is challenging Mr. Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 An amendment to the State Constitution that could pave the way for charitable groups to sponsor so-called Las Vegas Nights in New York was narrowly approved by the state's voters last month, the official tally showed today.

Oedipal passions seem so natural to Martha Graham that they are scarcely complex. However her "Night Journey," which was given for the first time this season at the Mark Hellinger Theater last night, this retelling of the Oedipus and Jocasta story has a very special intensity. In Graham dramaturgy love is either very simple a collision of celestial bodies or quite convolutedly complicated.

Washington, State Commissioner for Regional and Local Health, were insufficient to prove that he had uncovered a new disease termed "pantosomatitis."
TRENTON, Dec. 15 The New Jersey Senate unanimously approved a bill tonight that would extend thoroughbred and harness racing in the state 100 days each yearly. The vote was 33 to 0.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 Domestic new car sales climbed more than 43 percent in early December to an annual selling rate of 8.9 million units, the highest this year.
VIPITENO, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden dominated both heats of the men's special slalom today and took the lead in the World Cup standings.

The Aluminum Association reported yesterday that industry shipments for the first nine months plunged 36.2 percent from the year-ago level. SAN DIEGO, Dec. 15 San Diego's largest football crowd of the season, 52,446, was only briefly disappointed tonight when it was learned that Joe Namath wouldn't start for the New York Jets "for disciplinary reasons." Their attention quick shifted to enjoying their team's solid 24-16 victory, only the second in 13 games for the Chargers.

ROME, Dec. 15 The Roman Catholic Church intensified its effort to mobilize voters in Italy against the Communist Party today with a new attack saying that "one cannot be a Christian and a Marxist at the same time."

One of the two elevatars at 200 East 16th Street was working a little yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 15 The Ford Administration is insisting on closer consultations with Israel in advance of any such sensitive political and military moves as the recent Israeli air raids against Palestinian targets in Lebanon, Israeli and American sources said today.

In advertising circles the old Schaefer beer campaign "The one beer to have when you're having more than one" was considered by many the most effective beer advertising around because it appealed to the heavy user who accounted for a major part of consumption.

Andre Colmar's new play, "Dancing for the Kaiser," which opened Sunday at the Circle Repertory Company, is designed to resemble an old play. It not only takes place in 1918, but it also could have been written in 1918. It is an intricate yarn about an American dancer (somewhat like Isadora Duncan) who srole as Oscar Wilde's Salome triggers a moral crisis and a political dispute in wartime London.
Football is said to prepare a college player for the bigger game of life. Football indeed, all sports are supposed to be as important to a student's development as logic, literature and philosophy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The Senate passed the tax-cut bill tonight, following what appeared to be the final collapse of efforts to reach a compromise with President Ford over a ceiling on next year's Government spending. The vote was 73 to 19.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 15 Israel's Finance Ministry has presented to the Cabinet an austerity budget designed to help slash the nation's deficit in the balance of payments and reduce political dependence on the United States.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 (Reuters) Common Market finance ministers today postponed indefinitely attempts to bring the Swiss franc into their joint currency float but agreed to associate Switzerland with their day-to-day currency support operations.

In one of the largest acquisition proposals in the nation's history, the General Electric Company the nation's largest maker of electric products ands power equipment, announced last night that it was planning to take over Utah International, Inc., a major United States mining company.
The orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Company has called a news conference for this morning to announce that it would strike the opera Jan. 1, if no new contract were agreed by then.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15 (AP) Top-ranked Indiana rallied from 4 points down to force an overtime, then subdued Kentucky, 77-68, in college basketball tonight before 16,615 fans.
YONKERS, Dec. 15 City Manager J. Emmett Casey refused today to resign despite efforts by Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, a Republican, and some Democrats on the City Council to force his ouster.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The United States has offered to sell 10 of its most sophisticated radar-surveillance planes to Iran at a price of $187 million each, Pentagon officials said today.

If you're not a man who can throw a baseball through the eye of a needle at 100 miles an hour or thread a golf ball consistently through every hazard man and nature can devise, perhaps the next best thing to be, these days, is a man whose name speaks of some familiarity with a needle, thread, cloth and design.
OTTAWA, Dec. 15 (AP) Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the departing United States ambas- sador might have stepped out of bounds in criticizing Canadian policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Senator Frank Church acknowledged today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Operations had uncovered evidence that President Kennedy and two reputed organized crime leaders had a close friendship with the same woman in 1961 and 1962. But he denied published suggestions that the committee had tried to cover up information about the matter.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 Sara Jane Moore was ruled mentally competent in Federal court today to change her plea to guilty of attempting to assassinate President Ford here on Sept. 22.

The Supreme Court yesterday refused to hear an appeal challenging the legality of the creation of a special term of the New York State Supreme Court to hear corruption cases presented by the special state prosecutor for New York City, Maurice H. Nadjari.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 11 With a blend of moderate methods but revolutionary goals, the new Communist rulers of Laos have begun transforming the gentle people of this nation into a more regimented, spartan society.

Clair L. Stong, engineer, science writer and conductor of the "Amateur Scientist" column in the monthly Scientific American, died last Tuesday of cancer at his home in Dongan Hills, S.I. He was 73 years old and also lived in Vresco, Pa.

Robert L. Garner, a vice president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in its early years and the first president of its affiliate, the International Finance Corporation, died Saturday in Oklahoma City, where he was visiting his daughter. He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Individuals who take their tax returns to the Internal Revenue Service for help can expect accurate assistance less than half the time, a House Government Operations subcommittee was told today.

"It has no tinsel no sequins," Betty Ford pointed out yesterday as she led a tour of the White House Christmas tree and decorations, now open to public viewing. Soybean and grain futures prices moved downward again yesterday, following through on the sharp break in prices last Friday. Some soybean contracts made new life-of-contract lows, including March delivery, which closed at $4.55 , off 3 cents a pound, after being as low as $4.49 a bushel.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the arbiter of accounting practices, announced yesterday that companies taking losses or writedowns in accordance with a previously announced ruling must restate earnings for several years rather than lumping the charges together on one year's statement, as decided earlier.

MANILA, Dec. 17 Amid growing clamor for a better deal far labor, President Ferdinand E. Marcos today partly relaxed the ban on strikes and picketing imposed six weeks ago. He also decreed a wage increase for lowest-income earners.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17 Judith Campbell Exner maintained today that, although she had had a close personal relationship with President Kennedy while she was dating two leaders of a Chicago crime syndicate, she had never acted as an intermediary between the Mafia and the White House.

Miguel Najdorf, now 65 years old, is still going strong, as he proved in sharing first prize in the Argentine championship with his fellow grandmaster Oscar Panno. This was the eighth time that Najdorf "El Viejo," as he is known in Buenos Aires has captured top honors in the series, which began in 1921.

PARIS, Dec. 17 Through the efforts of Arab nations, a UNESCO conference today inserted the United Nations General Assembly's anti-Zionism resolution into an official document of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
Harness racing's failure to designate which horses are pulling a controversial new sulky has touched off protests from offtrack bettors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 The Senate confirmed the nomination of Judge John Paul Stevens to the Supreme Court by a vote of 98 to 0 today after just five minutes of discussion.
ROME, Dec. 17 (Reuters) The Italian Parliament today enacted a law that decriminalizes possession for personal use of small quantities of illegal drugs.
Howard M. Love, 45, was elected president and chief operating officer of the National Steel Corporation yesterday. He was also named a director and member of the executive committee.
The union representing the Metropolitan Opera orchestra yesterday broke off negotiations with the Met after a 15-minute meeting aimed at averting a strike Jan. 1.

Richard Rubin, a 35-yearold Queens lawyer, went through the final clearances yesterday leading to appointment as leader of New York City's lobbying staff in Albany.

Dr. Celestine L. Smith, former National Y.W.C.A. human relations specialist and a practicing psychologist, died Sunday in Mount Holly, N.J. She was 72 years old and lived in Medford Leas, N.J.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 The state employees union, facing a proposal from Governor Carey for a wage freeze, counterattacked today by issuing a summary of salary increases and promotions that the Governor had granted in recent months to his own staff of appointees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on a $6.5 billion compromise bill to reorganize the seven bankrupt Northeast railroads into a new Government-operated corporation and to aid other troubled carriers around the nation.

A coalition of public interest and church groups has petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to require corporate disclosure of foreign payoffs and political contributions. The agency was asked to make corporate officers and auditors personally liable for misleading statements about such transactions.

OAKLAND, Dec. 18 Chuck Tanner, dropped yesterday as manager of the Chicago White Sox, became Charley Finley's 11th manager in 16 years today as the owner of the Oakland A's hired him to take over the American League's fivetime Western Division champions.
KILAUEA VOLCANO, Hawaii, Dec. 18 Nature and Spreading Civilization tested each other last month here on the south slope of this geologically young island.
The Pillsbury Company, a major diversified food concern, reported yesterday profit increases of 21.1 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 22.5 percent for the half year ended Nov. 30.
An official of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company said here yesterday that the company expected to raise prices next year "by 7 to 8 percent."
SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 19 The Prime Minister of South Korea, Kim Jong Pil, and his entire Cabinet submitted their resignations en masse this morning to President Park Chung Hee.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18--Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser announced tonight a complete restructuring of the Federal Government and named his 24-member Cabinet to head the new departments.

Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of Manhattan removed yesterday the three executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, and assessed damages and fines totaling $9,252,000 against the executors, Frank Lloyd and Mr. Lloyd's Marlborough Galleries.

The new standards for admission to the City University could cut minority enrollment in next fall's freshman class by more than two-thirds and eventually leave the university with the same racial composition it had before the open-admissions policy was begun five years ago, according to a study by the Board of Higher Education.
EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 18 Intrastate conflicts mark the 1976 racing schedule released today by the New Jersey Racing Commission.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 18, (Reuters) The Common Market today gave support to women's rights campaigners by outlawing all sex discrimination in jobs, informed sources said.
The company that builds the Flexible Flyers that have taken generations of red-cheeked American children down snowy hills has found today's economic conditions tough sledding.

ATLANTA, Dec. 18 (AP) Dwight Jones, 18-year-old Bill Willoughby and John Drew combined to score 28 points in the fourth quarter tonight as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 114-98, in a National Basketball Association game.

The modest gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from an anonymous donor in Philadelphia and from Dorothy P. Stewart of Manhattan were accompanied by letters noting that even though the economic downturn affected their own lives they still wanted to help others who were in more dire straits.
CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 18 Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on a charge of extorting $25,000 from a financier seeking a state bank charter.

The chairman of the State Mediation Board, Vincent D. McDonnell, offered yesterday to assist the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra members in reaching a contract settlement that would avert a strike threatened Jan. 1.
A Manhattan grand jury has found insufficient evidence to indict an off-duty police officer who fatally shot a 16-year-old Long Island youth during a curbside dispute in mid-Manhattan on Nov. 4.
GEORGETOWN, Del., Dec. 18 A 17-year-old Georgetown youth faces hanging after being convicted today of murder and rape by a Superior Court jury.
A building on the Upper West Side was picketed yesterday by residents who charged that a place of prostitution was being operated in one of the apartments there.

Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, who served as Army Chief of Staff from Oct. 1, 1962, through July 3, 1964, and then as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff until he retired in 1970, died yesterday afternoon at Frederick (Md.) Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 18 (AP) Israel turned over to Egypt today the bodies of 93 soldiers killed in the Middle East wars of 1967 and 1973 the military command announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Federal Election Commission certified today that President Ford and two Democrats, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, of Texas and former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, were eligible for Federal matching campaign funds.

Archie Griffin of Ohio State and Fran Tarkenton of the Minnesota Vikings, two "little" football players who have never missed a game, were named college and pro player of the year, respecttively, by the Maxwell Memorial Football Club of Philadelphia yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Attorney General Edward H. Levi has appointed Michael Shaheen Jr. as the Justice Department's counsel on professional responsibility and the head of a new office to oversee investigations of alleged misconduct by department employees.

Jimmy Carter said here yesterday that he "never intended to yield to Governor Carey nor to any other favorite son" in his quest for the Democratic nomination for President, and he called "unfortunate" the New York law that bans the listing of Presidential candidates on the ballot along with delegates pledged to them.

Surrogate Millard L. Midonick's momentous decision against Frank Lloyd, the Marlborough Galleries and the executors of the Mark Rothko estate was the talk of a stunned art world yesterday, and particularly of the tight little world of dealers on 57th Street and upper Madison Avenue.
HAMPTON, Va., Dec. 18 (UPI) Ticky Burden, a rookie, scored 33 points tonight to help the Virginia Squires snap a five-game losing streak with a 94-90 overtime victory over the New York Nets.
When Helen McDonagh, five months pregnant, came out of St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Riverdale yesterday morning behind her husband's coffin, she was dry-eyed and composed.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 Governor Carey, faced with a choice of settling for a reduced tax package or ending the year with no new taxes at all, accepted today the package designed by the Legislature's leadership that will yield $600 million in increased business taxes over the next 15 months.

Public television's Classic Theater series, imported from the British Broadcasting Corporation, is brought to an appropriate conclusion this week with a quite respectable production of George Bernard Shaw's "Mrs. Warren's Profession." It will be broadcast tonight at 8 on Channels 21 and 31, and tomorrow at 9 on Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)--The Environmental Protection Agency announced today the official fuel-economy performances of 24 more 1976-model automobiles, with three of them beating the previous gasoline mileage record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The United States Golf Association, the governing body that traditionally has maintained a frosty remoteness from the rest of the world, made a move today toward thawing its attitude.

The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Ken Rosewall of Australia, the top-seeded player, required only 15 minutes to gain a quarterfinal spot today in the men's singles of the New South Wales international open tennis championship. Finishing a third-round match interrupted by rain yesterday.

Adaptations of seven Mark Twain stories will be broadcast on the "CBS Radio Mystery Theater" for seven consecutive nights, beginning Jan. 5, mark ing the start of the program's third year on the air.

Sales of shares in mutual funds fell in November to $786.6 million from $913.7 million in October but outpaced the year-ago total of $619.3 million, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

For the first time since 1920, the "Trittico" of Puccini held the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where it had had its world premiere in 1918. Of the three one-act operas of "11 Trittico," the most popular, "Gianni Schicchi," had already been seen at the Metropolitan Opera last season, paired with Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle."

The city's successful appeal of the Grand Central case comes as a welcome Christmas gift for New Yorkers. The decision that overturned a lower-court denial of landmark designation is a triumph for the city and for the propriety, integrity and constitutionality of the landmarks law and for some of the enduring values that make a city great.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 (AP) Seven terrorist gunmen ended a 16day siege at the Indonesian Consulate today, symbolically lowering the flag they had hoisted as representing their Pacific homeland of South Molucca and freeing 25 hostages.

No matter how staunchly stoic one may be about avoiding sweets the year round, Christmas dinner is usually the occasion for a permissible lapse of resolve. Darkly rich mincemeats, nut and currant-studded fruit cakes exotically spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves, clouds of whipped cream and golden seas of custard, rum-scented chestnut purees and snowy rice molds are as essential to the Yuletide celebration as wreaths of holly, tinseled trees and children caroling.

Ann Marcy Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Latimer Richards of Mantoloking, N.J., was married here last evening to Steven Morris Hartig, son of Albert Hartig of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Joyce Beeman Hartig. The Rev. John B. Coburn performed the ceremony in St. James' Episcopal Church.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) George McGinnis's heroics in the final minute of regulation time and then in overtime enabled the Philadelphia 76ers to rally for a 115-114 N.B.A. victory over the undermanned Detroit Pistons tonight.
Moving away from his long support of free education at the City University, Governor Carey indicated yesterday that he thought students who could afford to pay should be made to do so.

Spokesmen for the banking, retailing and printing industries charged yesterday that the proposed state tax package is punitive, will drive more companies out of New York and also will act to arrest economic recovery.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 19 (AP) Top-ranked Indiana, paced by Scott May's 18 points, whipped Georgia, 9356, in the opening game of Indiana's basketball tournament tonight, giving Coach Bobby Knight his 200th career victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) Charles Gaynor, who wrote the sketches, lyrics and music for such Broadway shows as "Lend an Ear" and "Show Girl," died yesterday at the age of 66.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 19 Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia pleaded not guilty today to a Federal extortion charge, and was promised a trial in four months.

The Public Broadcasting Service, aided by a $700,000 grant from the Exxon Corporation, has obtained 100 motion picture classics from the collection of Janus Films Inc., which will be offered to individual public television stations to play at their discretion.

Murray Louis has been having a busy season mounting ballets in Berlin, Madrid and Copenhagen but he and his company have come home for the holidays. Last night they opened their current New York season at the New York University Theater, and it will run through Jan. 10.
For the First time, Mickey Lolich strolled through the New York Mets' clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday as most onlookers stared at the belly that hung over his brown belt.

Any discussion about the world's resources, more particularly its rawmaterial supplies, which seeks to avoid being an exercise in escapism must face the fundamental issue of whether there is an equitable consumption and exploitation of global natural resources and, if not, what is to be done about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19(Reuters) Canada and the United States agreed today to remove quota restrictions on trading in beef between the two countries, Canada's Agriculture Minister, Eugene Whelan, announced here.
The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration yesterday rejected the PATH transit-line extension project as far too costly as planned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 President Ford vetoed today a $45 billion appropriation for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfare but still faced difficult political decisions on legislation on energy and construction site picketing.

The State Health Department yesterday disclosed plans to transfer four nursing homes here from their operator, who has been indicted on charges of Medicaid fraud, to nonprofit institutions. It predicted that a substantial number of such transfers would be needed as a result of criminal prosecutions in the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The Senate voted overwhelmingly today for a cutoff of funds for covert military support operations in Angola, a move President Ford immediately deplored as "a deep tragedy for all countries whose security depends on the United States."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 19 (AP) Eleven persons were killed and 14 wounded today in mortar and machine-gun exchanges between Christian and Moslem gunmen, officials reported.

Dr. Bert K. Kusserow, professor of pathology at the University of Vermont College of Medicine, who was noted for his work toward the development of an artificial heart, died Thursday in Burlington Vt. He was 51 years old and lived in Underhill, Vt.
The State Superior Court yesterday granted pet dealers a stay in the execution of a new state regulation that requires an "animal history certificate" to be provided with each pet sale.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 The Legislature moved slowly tonight toward passing a $600 million package of increased business taxes, the result of a bipartisan compromise designed to restore the state's ability to borrow money by closing a substantial portion of the state budget gap.
Fess Williams, jazz band leader of the 1920's and 1930's, died Wednesday at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived at 106-47 Waltham Street, Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Canada and the United States agreed today to remove quota restrictions on trading in beef between the two countries, Canada's Agriculture Minister, Eugene Whelan, announced here.

What a pleasant surprise to discover, in the hubbub of the Christmas season, a show by an artist hitherto unfamiliar an artist having his first one-man show in New York, in fact that is a solid and splendid accomplishment!
Edna Marguerite Moor-Jones, a founder of the Broadway Grand Opera Association, died Friday in Wingdale, N.Y. She would have been 85 on Dec. 24.

Frank Sully, a character actor whose features were familiar to a generation and more of moviegoers, died Wednesday at the Motion Picture Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills, near the Hollywood where he spent most of his career. He was 67 years old.

Meanwhile, in New Jersey, the case involving the convictions of Rubin Carter and John Artis becomes "curiouser and curiouser." While the application for a new trial makes its tortured way through the New Jersey court system and the Passaic County prosecutor's office stoutly defends the virtue of its original prosecution, doubts arising from the trial steadily increase.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Congress passed the tax-cut-bill tonight after incorporating a nonbinding commitment, acceptable to President Ford, to control Government spending.

NEWARK, Dec. 19 (UPI) Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of Bergen County, did not show up for his seventh scheduled grand-jury appearance today because Congress had passed a resolution barring his testimony while the House was in session.

Carlos Andres Perez, President of Venezuela, said yesterday his country should not continue producing and selling as much oil as it has in the past. Venezuela is the largest foreign oil supplier to the United States.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP) Moscow attacked America's United Nations representative, Daniel P. Moynihan, today, calling him a political wheeler-dealer pandering to the "Zionist" vote and "a very eccentric person, capable of shocking even diplomats who have seen a lot in their lifetime."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 (AP) Seven terrorist gunmen ended a 16day siege at the Indonesian Consulate today, symbolically lowering the flag they had hoisted as representing their Pacific homeland of South Molucca and freeing 25 hostages.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 Banking officials, stunned by legislative proposals for increases in their taxes, cautioned today that even if the levies were approved in full, the state would still have to take several steps before credit was restored to its construction agencies or the state itself.
Six members of the Rooney family pay themselves combined salaries of $750,000 a year from Yonkers Raceway profits, Timothy Rooney acknowledged yesterday.
After 27 years of carrying bags at the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South, Donald Karabaich became an actor yesterday.

The expansion of two existing ferry services between Long Island and Connecticut is preferable at this time to the establishment of new routes across Long Island Sound, according to a study by the TriState Regional Planning Commission released yesterday.

Harry Rauch, who retired as vice president for public relations of the Young Rubicam advertising agency eight years ago, died Thursday in Cobbleskill, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Middleburg, N.Y.
NEWARK, Dec. 19 (AP) The license of a New Milford mortician has been revoked after it was learned that he substituted a $35 plain pine box for a $1,475 cherry-wood coffin for a cremation.

NARASHINO, Japan, Dec. 19 (AP) Curtis Strange, the 1974 National Collegiate champion from Wake Forest, won the individual laurels, and the United States took the team honors today in a three-day collegiate golf match against Japan. Strange posted a three under-par 69 in the final round for a 54-hole total of 208, and the eight-man United States team beat Japan, 2614.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) The Port of Long Beach was named today as the major West Coast supertaanker terminal for oil from Alaska's North Slope, ending a year of competition with Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 National efforts to make Americans alert to the dangers of high blood pressure seem to be proving effective, specialists said today.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market declined yesterday in accelerated trading.

Working in his laboratory in Boston where he is surrounded by advance celebrations of the nation's Bicentennial, Dr. Don W. Fawcett decided to start celebrating another 1976 anniversary that to him has even greater significance the tricentennial of the discovery of the sperm.
SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 19 President Park Chung Hee today appointed a new Cabinet, headed by one of the President's assistants and including two others.

Court reformers hoped for a miraculous turnaround in the last few days as the final votes were counted on Constitutional Amendment No. 3. But the official tally shows that the effort to unify the administration and financing of the state court system was defeated by a 17,448 vote margin. This result apparently grew out of an unreasonable fear that unified courts would somehow add to the tax burden; the contrary is true.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 Massachusetts, whose reputation for liberalism was enhanced when it was the only state carried by Senator George McGovern in the 1972 Presidential election, may provide some major surprises early in the 1976 campaign.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 The Chrysler Corporation wanted to give the British Government the keys to its ailing United Kingdom subsidiary. The origins of the soup, its name and various components are something of enigma, for no one can guess the date of its entrance into the native culture.

Joseph F. McManus, retired chief of the construction evaluation section of the Veterans Administration, died Sunday in Philadelphia, where he had been living in a retirement home. He was 79 years old and a former resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Edwin H. Yeo 3d, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that the aim of the forthcoming sales of gold by the International Monetary Fund was not to depress the market price of gold but to make use of a "now-immobilized asset" of the fund to help the balance-of-payments position of the world's poorest countries.

Wild Jr., kep figure in the operation of the Gulf Oil Corporation's $5 million domestic political slush fund, appeared today to have been the key development that prompted the corporation's internal investigative committee to ask for a 15-day delay in filing its report two weeks ago.

UIGE, Angola In terms of their personal background, the three leaders of Angola's battling nationalist factions have a great deal in common. All three are the sons of Protestant lay preachers in a country that is predominantly Roman Catholic. All were educated in mission schools and all were part of that tiny segment of Angola's black population that had risen to middle-class respectability.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI) The American Motors Corporation announced today a $40 price rise on three jeep models, but said it had no plans to increase sticker prices of its cars. The increase on the four-wheel drive jeep Chero kee, wagoneer and truck models was necessary because new shoulder-belt systems will be installed after Jan. 1 under a new Federal safety standard. The price adjustments will apply to orders received after Jan. 1.

The Rev. Edwin A. Quain, a Fordham University teacher and administrator, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.

Students on college campuses, preparing for the holidays, have taken the time to remember those less fortunate and are turning up in increasing numbers in the list of contributors to the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Federal Reserve Board and its staff now believe that the recent erratic and puzzling movements of the nation's money supply demand deposits and currency may have been caused in considerable part by a little-noticed change in banking regulations that permits businesses to have savings accounts in banks.

Cocoa futures dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the New York Cocoa Exchange under some heavy profit taking. Speculators, who had bought cocoa futures last week, were in the market selling following the rise of the March contract to a new contract high of 65.50 cents a pound on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Federal financing of political campaigns, one of the major reforms enacted after Watergate, began today when the Federal Election Commission authorized the Treasury Department to make initial payments totaling $2.6 million to the two major political parties and to 11 Presidential contenders.
NEWARK, Dec. 23 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that police superiors may discipline lower-ranking officers who disparage them in public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 New York City school officials and the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, reached a compromise today that should avert legal action against five local school districts that have failed to cooperate with a civil-rights investigation.

Wells Fargo Company announced yesterday that it expected a charge of about $3.5 million, or about 18 cents a share, against income for 1975. A Chinese lacquer betrothal screen for $30,000. Or perhaps a pocket toothbrush mounted in nine-carat gold a virtual bargain at only $440.
