Justice Nathaniel Helman of State Supreme Court has ruled that the New York City police have no right to ask persons to establish "need" when they apply to keep a pistol in their homes or businesses.

CAPETOWN South Africa's Prime Minister John Vorster, the 60-year-old National Party leader who has been guiding his country through storms for almost a decade, has a well-articulated principle of leadership. "I have always thought," he told me, "that a leader must walk in front of his people; but he should never go so far as to move out of their sight and hearing."

A ruling by a Public Service Commission examiner yesterday cut a Consolidated Edison request for a 29.3 percent increase in electric rates to 6.4 percent, the largest reduction in a utility rate case on record in the state.

Despite predictions earlier this year of a 5 percent increase in electric power sales by the nation's investor-owned electric utilities, the gain in 1975 will be less than 2 percent over 1979, a year when no growth was registered.

The city is initiating an investigation to determine whether extensive corruption uncovered among people in the construction and real-estate industries and employees in the Buildings Department may have played a role in city supervision of the Blue Angel nightclub, where seven people died in a fire last Thursday.

It's Christmas and as the old song lyrics go, you'd better watch out only it isn't Santa who's looking. Retail store security forces are taking anything but a "ho ho" attitude toward shoplifters, whose busiest season is now.
STONE HARBOR, Dec. 23 (AP)--A year after a northeaster uncovered her timbers, the bones of an old sailing ship remain a mystery on the beach of this Cape May County resort.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The Luanda radio said today that serious fighting was going on in central Angola between forces of two allied nationalist groups the Union for the Total Independence of Angola and the National Front for the Liberation of Angola.

A labor arbitrator ruled yesterday that two pitchers, Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally, were free agents who were no longer bound by their baseball contracts and could sell their services to the highest bidder.
An off-duty police officer fatally shot two men on Staten Island late Monday who, he said, had posed as drivers of a "gypsy" cab and had tried to rob him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) James F. Lee, a journalist for 48 years and a writer for U.S. News World Report from 1959 until his retirement this year, died Monday at Georgetown Hospital. He was 70 years old.

Glamour stocks some of them depressed lately by the pressure of tax-loss selling snapped back to life yesterday to lead a fairly strong advance. Airline issues moved higher, while the gold stocks lost ground.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Serious crime reported in the United States rose 11 percent in the first nine months of 1975, but the rate of increase was less than for the same period a year ago, according to F.B.I, statistics released today.

The closest game in the divisional playoffs this weekend will be Sunday's Cincinnati-Oakland contest. That is the view of Bud Goode, the noted sports analyst who has fed 123 statistical parts into the CalComp computer to determine what should happen at Pittsburgh and Los Angeles on Saturday and at Bloomington, Minn., and Oakland on Sunday.

Hardly anyone will notice, but the New York City Ballet will do "The Nutcracker" today for the 700th time. Some people think of "Nutcracker" as The Show, the way other people think of Harvard-Yale as The Game, and it is a fact that grown men in "Nutcracker" audiences weep sloppily when the Christmas tree rises up from the stage in Act One. It gets them every time.

The Junior Assembly, held during the Thanksgiving holidays for the last four years, took place in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza last night. Mrs. Charles C. Lee Jr., this year's chairman, explained the switch in schedule this way: "So many girls and boys don't come home for Thanksgiving we thought Christmas might be more festive."
THE COMMON STREAM, By Rowland Parker, 283 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart and Winston, $8.95

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 23--Under mounting public criticism, Connecticut's Commission on Special Revenue, decided today to reconsider its decision two weeks ago to deny Barry Brunelle a $10,000 state lottery prize because he was only 17 and too young to have bought a ticket legally.

The Christmas shopping season the principal reflection of the buying mood of Americans and a major indicator of 1976 economic trends is concluding this year with an unusually strong flourish across the nation, topping last year's sales levels by 10 to 15 percent and 1973's by even more.

Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday, in an unaudited statement, a net loss of $15.6 million for November, compared with a $15.7 million loss in the year-earlier month, which had the benefit of a $7.6 million tax credit. Operating revenues increased 5.2 percent, while operating expenses were 1.6 percent less than in November 1974. Last month's results were adversely affected by a $1.1 million provision for mutual aid payments to a struck carrier.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Dec. 24 A large force of left wing guerrillas tried to seize an army arsenal 10 miles south of here last night, the army said early today. A communique said that at least 50 of the attackers were killed and that shooting was continuing in the area.

Certain Irish "relief" organizations in this country are reputed to be the source of as much as 85 percent of the weapons used by radical terrorists of the Irish Republican Army, according to a report published in The Times a few days ago.

Obviously, the arbitration award making Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally free agents came as no surprise to the men who own baseball, for they already had a paper prepared and signed firing the arbitrator. As soon as Peter Seitz delivered his opinion, John Gaherin, the owners' representative in labor matters, handed him a letter dismissing him as umpire in grievance cases.
Seven Minnesota Vikings, led by Fran Tarkenton and Chuck Foreman, have been selected to start for the National Football Conference team on Jan. 26 in the annual Pro Bowl.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP) The European Economic Community Commission has decided that the financial aid envisaged by the British Government for Chiysler United Kingdom Ltd. is compatible with Common Market treaty rules. a commission spokesman announced today. The commission also went along with limited import restrictions announced by the British Government in London last week even though it reiterated its opinion that unilateral import curbs were inopportune, the spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, warning that SovietAmerican tensions might rise, said today that the Ford Administration would continue to oppose through available military aid and diplomatic means the imposition of a Sovietbacked regime in Angola by force.
SCRANTON, Pa. Could it be that Ebenezer Scrooge was merely the victim of bad public relations?
With a little help from the outside, Superman came to the rescue.

Just a year ago, Dave Matthews's 12-piece jazz band began playing on Monday nights at the Five Spot, 2 St. Marks Place, with Mr. Matthews hoping that the club might be a steady Monday night base for the band, as the Village Vanguard has been for the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Band since 1966.

Frank E. King, considered the prima suspect in the "French Connection" theft of $70 million worth of narcotics from police custody, and three other former members of a now-defunct police narcotics unit were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting thousands of dollars from major drug dealers.

ALGIERS, Dec. 23 (Reuters) A group of pro-Palestinian guerrillas who burst into an oil ministers' meeting in Vienna on Sunday freed the last of their hostages at the airport here early today and rode into Algiers by car.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) The United States in 1977 will be forced to import 50 percent more oil than it does today, a Library of Congress study says.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in another effort to scale down operations in line with reduced budgets, has proposed a plan to realign the mission responsibilities of several of its research centers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 23 The first official American delegation to visit Hanoi since the end of the Vietnam war arrived here today and reported that agreement had been reached that "acts of reciprocity" should be a part of improving relations.

Three men reputed to be among the top narcotics dealers in the city were found not guilty yesterday after a trial that contained references to several murdered witnesses, numerous heroin deliveries and millions of dollars in cash.

Students on college campuses, preparing for the holidays, have taken the time to remember those less fortunate and are turning up in increasing numbers in the list of contributors to the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23 For the first time since Colorado approved the practice nearly 20 years ago, a state supreme court has promulgated a rule that would allow television broadcasting from courtrooms.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 23 (UPI) John McKay, the Southern California coach, didn't send his team into the Liberty Bowl last night against Texas A. and M. with a plea to win his last collegiate game for him. That's never been his style.

William P. Rogers, the former Secretary of State under Richard M. Nixon, was elected yesterday to The Jockey Club. Rogers is also a trustee of the New York Racing Association. As a member of The Jockey Club he joins an exclusive group, whose function is to register all thoroughbreds in this country, Canada and Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Investigators for the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence have declined to examine fully the file compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the activities of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., despite an offer from the Justice Department to make the complete file available to the committee staff.

HILLSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 21 Executive clemency at Christmas for a Columbia County woman in jail for murdering her husband in 1968 is being sought by 18 state legislators, a dozen organizations, several prison officials, two district attorneys and a committee of convicts.

The United States, which led the world into the most serious recession since World War II, is expected to lead it out again in 1976. Yet the recovery in the major industrial countries is expected to be so sluggish as to make little or no dent in unemploy ment the worst since the end of the Depression of the 1930's.
Rabbi Avigdor Cyperstein, a Talmudic scholar, died yesterday in Jerusalem, Israel. He was 70 years old.

HOUSTON, Dec. 23 A Federal judge has ordered sweeping reforms in the administration and conditions of the Harris County jail system. In a report issued last week, Judge Carl O. Bue Jr. of Federal District Court, said, "severe and inhumane overcrowding" existed, and he hinted that he might order the closing of the jail facilities if the county did not comply with his order.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP) Julius Erving led the way with 31 points and Rich Jones added 21 tonight as the New York Nets downed the Kentucky Colonels, 107102, in an American Basketball Association game.

President Ford's decision to veto the bitterly disputed construction "situs picketing" bill puts first things first. In terms of the national interest the sole relevant yardstick there never was any sound argument for enacting a law that could only make for more and bigger strikes and a further rise in the already astronomic cost of building.
Five-year-old Tulio Arroyo, child of divorce, may or may not get a Tiny Mighty Mo truck for Christmas tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Senator Birch Bayh is young, liberal and a relatively fresh face on the national scene. But as a candidate for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination and as a political technician he may be the most orthodox and traditional figure in the field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) President Ford has commuted the prison sentences of two convicted murderers, a move that makes them eligibe for parole soon, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Marcel Dionne got his third three-goal game of the season tonight, providing the margin in the Los Angeles Kings's 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League. The burst gave Dionne the league lead with 24 goals.

Most New York City businesses plan to close early for Christmas Eve, according to a survey by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and there will be extra trains on commuter railroads to handle the prospective exodus.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (UPI) Some 400,000 tourists have swarmed into Florida for the ChristmasNew Year's holiday, filling most hotels along both coasts, travel industry authorities say. And 100,000 more are expected.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The European Boxing Union will not allow Jean-Pierre Coopman of Belgium to challenge Muhammad Ali for the world heavyweight title, a British boxing official said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 The nation's holiday buying rush is almost over, and many retail stores are optimistically reporting better sales than in 1974. But it hasn't been a bountiful holiday season for many Americans especially among the hard-core unemployed who had hoped to increase their income with a temporary Christmas job.
W. Bernard Carlson Jr., a principal in the New York law firm of Miller Carlson, died Monday, in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, N.J. He was 51 years old and lived in West Long Branch, N.J.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Governor Byrne said today that he would fight "tooth and nail" to prevent the construction of oil refineries along the New Jersey coastline, even if it means he must go to court.

JINGLE BELLS Alexander Schneider, who has become as much a Christmas Eve tradition in New York, as Santa Claus, will be giving his seventh annual concert at midnight tonight at Carnegie Hall. Actually, tonight's performance with the New York String Orchestra is part of a series of holiday concerts by Mr. Schneider.
Despite advice from the city that the school system will not get a larger budget for l976-77, school authorities are planning to ask for $435 million in additional money.

The best "Messiah" in town this season took place Monday night in the dining room of a West Side apartment. This was chamber music pushed to its jolliest extreme: a harpsichord and chamber orchestra, soloists and a chorus of 25 all of them performing for free and handily outnumbering their audience crammed into a room that measured 18 feet by 22 feet.

DALLAS, Dec. 23 A jury of 10 men and two women decided today that the 9-yearold son of a self-described lesbian should be taken from his mother and placed in the custody of his father.
Samuel Rudin, a leading builder and owner of residential and office real estate, died Monday in his home at 945 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.
EUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23 The Argentine armed forces have emerged from a limited air force crisis apparently more united and determined to control national affairs.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 The United States auto industry wound up 1975 with production of 6,725,682 cars, down 8 percent from 1974.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange yesterday closed higher while those in the overthe-counter market ended mixed.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, accused of stock fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission last August, signed a consent decree here yesterday settling the Government case without admitting or denying the allegations of the Government agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Roman Catholic and Baptist theologians have concluded their first dialogue on the question of abortion without reaching a mutual position on the issue, but jointly affirmed "the sacredness of life."

A 52-year-old woman who made almost daily visits to a 72-year-old diabetic friend was shot to death yesterday by an intruder who also wounded the older woman.

Chris Evert, winner of 14 tournaments, including the United States Open, and $350,000, has been ranked No. 1 in the country for the second straight year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Food and Drug Administration has made it clear to manufacturers of one class of birth control pills that they must produce evidence that there is a group of women who have a special need for pills of that particular type, a spokesman for the agency said today.

Sums investors who bought A-rated New York City bonds less than a year ago only to see them drop to deep discounts in the flurry over possible default realize now that an investment-grade rating is not an absolute assurance that nothing will go wrong.

Like an echo bouncing back and forth across New York, the sound of music and Christmas carols are sweetening the harsh cacophony of the city these days as New Yorkers prepare for Christmas.

At Pildes Opticians on Nassau Street many employes call the boss Danny. He is Daniel Pildes, the 32year-old son of Harry Pildes, who founded the business at 80 Nassau Street 50 years ago. Harry Pildes has retired.

President Ford showed a firm grasp in locating the public interest and conflicting values when he signed into law the comprehensive Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975. Resisting the insistent wiles of the petroleum industry and the political contributions and influence which the oilmen might bring to bear in next year's election Mr. Ford correctly perceived that, on balance, enactment of this complex measure would benefit the public far more than its veto.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 23 Full-time workers in search of a college degree and experience-hungry management students at the University of Utah are changing places this year as part of an "educational trade-off" career development program funded by a two-year $100,000 grant from the United States Office of Education.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23--The New York Knicks, with a balanced attack, broke a road jinx tonight by defeating the Milwaukee Bucks in a National Basketball Association game, 110-108. John Gianelli's 15-footer from the side was the clinching shot.

MADRID, Dec. 23 Some small steps, including the settlement of a Madrid taxi strike today without incident, have been interpreted here as the first signs that the Government will move to carry out the new policy announced over the weekend by Interior Minister Manuel Fraga Iribarne that the Government intends to distinguish between "adversaries" and "enemies."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) President Ford has commuted the prison sentences of two convicted murderers, a move that makes them eligible for parole soon, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

UNION, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP) Jim McGlothlin, who compiled a 14-10 won-lost record while helping the Cincinnati Reds win a pennant and pitched in two World Series games in 1970, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 32 years old.

VIENNA, Dec. 23 M.O. Feyide, a Nigerian who is Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting. Countries, said today that it was the Austrian authorities who had determined the appropriate security measures for protecting OPEC headquarters during ministerial meetings.
LISBON, Dec. 23 Lisbon shops were full of Christmas joy today but short of such vital necessities as milk, butter and eggs.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 23 (AP) A 56-year-old woman, jailed 11 years ago as the leader of a religious cult who was too dangerous to be allowed to be free, was released today by President Kenneth D. Kaunda.
When we last left the Rangers on Sunday, they had picked up a victory despite dull, uninspired hockey that put Madison Square Garden in a trance.
NEWARK, Dec. 23 (UPI) The South Jersey Gas Company today was granted a $5.3 million rate increase which will raise utility bills an average of 14 percent.

Governor Carey yesterday named two justices of the State Supreme Court, Harold Birns and Samuel J. Silverman, as justices of the Appellate Division, First Department.

Jacques A. Mitchell Jr. treasurer of McKesson Robbins Company in New York from 1948 until his retirement in 1966, died Tuesday of cancer in the Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, Vt. Mr. Mitchell, who lived in Dorset, Vt., was 69 years old.

Two scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have disputed the widely held belief that there is a clearcut limit on the magnitude of great earthquakes. They propose that some may be four times as strong as any recorded in recent years.

Two years ago, Union Carbide Company began a painstaking study of whether it should give up its handsome 50-story headquarters tower on Park Avenue and move most of its staff of 3,600 out of New York City.
TALLINN, U.S.S.R. It took three years in the early 15th century to build the town hall of Tallinn along its majestic Gothic lines. Four years have just been spent putting it back in mint condition.

No one who has ever seen Murray Louis dance has to he reminded of his extraordinary skills, but few are aware of just how long he has maintained his special level or artistry. On Tuesday evening Program II of his company's current season at New York University's School of Education auditorium gave a 20-year retrospective of his fascinating career.

The New York Stock Exchange told member brokers yesterday that a Government order liberalizing rules against doing business away from the exchange's trading floor would be replaced by a new rule that still retained trading restrictions on round-lot orders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund's executive board approved yesterday a new and enlarged compensatory financing facility, monetary sources said here.

The church of St. Mary-le-Bow in Cheapside, London, puts on lunchtime dialogues between its rector, the Rev. Joseph McCulloch, and guest speakers. Mr. McCulloch was chided in The Times of London recently for bullying a guest, Germaine Greer, the feminist scholar. With tongue somewhat in cheek, a Times commentator said Mr. McCulloch seemed "in the most boorish and Devilish of moods."
NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 24 (AP) A sixth local policeman was arreted today as a result of an investigation into thefts and was charged with breaking into a liquor store earlier this year.

QUILMES, Argentina, Dec. 24 Soldiers killed at least 45 left-wing guerrillas who tried to storm an arsenal here in a battle that lasted until early today. With selling pressure notably absent, the stock market scored gains along a wide front yesterday in a shortened pre-Christmas session.

A Federal judge has accused a Federal prosecutor of resorting to a "Byzantine trap" and a "Catch-22" device to resist a lawsuit that assails conditions in the new Metropolitan Correctional Center near Foley Square.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 24 The United Natons has appealed to 77 governments to help the Comoro Islands. It says the former French colony is in "desperate need" of food, medicines and technical assistance.

The Oklahoma football team left home today and headed for its Orange Bowl date (in Miami) with Michigan on New Year's Night Without Horace Ivory, its No. 2 ground gainer. The Sooners' head coach, Barry Switzer, confirmed that Ivory had been dismissed from the squad for personal reasons.

There were tinsel and tinfoil andd stars and crowns and rouged little cheeks and eye-shadowed young eyes and harried teachers and anxious mothers. There were shepherds tripping on robes and one angel's wings getting caught on another's spectacles. There was darting and bobbing and giggling and nudging.

On Christmas Day, year after year, the Biblical story still bears a solemn message of faith, good tidings and renewal. Across the United States and the globe, religious observances and social celebrations bring joy to the home place. It is a holy day and a holiday: a time of prayerful second chances in our personal and national lives and a time of youthful visions of sugar plums dancing in our heads.

A wise man once said, "Bah, humbug." Someone else chimed in with, "God help us, each and every one" or words to that effect. And a third is known to have added to the season's joy by saying, "Here's Christmas at our throats again."

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4, 1968, are bound by a common thread the view that unnamed "interests," Southern, reactionary and white, had sensed in Dr. King's increasingly militant stance a new economic and poilitical threat that prompted his murder at their hands.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 (UPI) Paul Brown, whose football teams have posted more victories than those of any other coach, resigned tonight as head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals.

Dorothy Kirsten went out in a blaze of glory on New Year's Eve. Making her farewell appearance at the Metropolitan Opera after 30 years with the company in nothing but leading roles, she sang and acted the part of Tosca with the vocal control and dramatic acuity of a prima donna in midcareer.
Park East, a weekly newspaper that covered the Upper East Side for 12 years, has suspended publication indefinitely.
Lee Roy Jordan, one of the senior citizens of the Dallas Cowboys, refrained from roaring through a rousing New Year's Eve.

Ohio State went into the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., needing a victory to clinch the national championship, but it didn't get it; the University of California, Los Angeles, scored a 23-10 upset.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 Governor Byrne today ordered his cabinet officers to make 5 percent cuts in their departmental salary accounts in the coming year, raising the possibility of a substantial layoff of state employees in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Diffidence has never been an obvious political flaw in Hubert Horatio Humphrey. Even now, as a declared noncandidate for the Presidency after three futile tries, he remains an irrepressible and unabashed aspirant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 Hugh McMillen Hutton, editorial cartoonist for The Philadelphia Inquirer for 35 years, died today in a Philadelphia hospital. Mr. Hutton, who was 78 years old, never regained consciousness after suffering a stroke on Tuesday shortly after visiting his son in Alexandria. Va.
Dr. John V. D'Angelo, a former Bronx surgeon who had been on the staffs of Morrisania and Union Hospitals, died Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

DHANBAD, India, Jan. 2 A week ago tomorrow, as hundreds of men worked in two shafts 1,050 feet below ground at the Chasnala colliery, roofs above them gave way and poured millions of tons of water on them from an abandoned mine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. One major problem of the nuclear age is how to prevent crazy people from making and exploding nuclear bombs. Recently, on a television program, a bright student said he had designed a bomb in five weeks. That does not mean it will work or that he can make one by himself. Moreover, there are other places in society where he can create havoc more easily.

Dr. Arnold Treitman, a cardiologist and an instructor in cardiology at Stony Brook Medical College, died of a heart attack Thursday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived at 164 East Rockaway Road, Hewlett.

Max Robb, president of the City Stores Company, a national department-store chain, from 1958 to 1962, and since then chairman of the executive committee of the Bankers Securities Corporation in Philadelphia, parent company of City Stores, died Wednesday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 80 years old and lived in Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Treasury Department distributed $1.88 million to 11 Presidential contenders today, the nation's direct Federal campaign contributors.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP) Wake Forest lost its junior star, Skip Brown, with an injured thigh early in the second period but went on to send third-ranked North Carolina to its first loss, 9583, in the first round of the Big Four tournament tonight.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market advanced yesterday although volume slumped.

When Federal District Judge Earl Larson decided that the "Rozelle rule" violated the antitrust laws, he struck a blow against the fantasies with which owners of professional football teams have successfully cloaked their operations. He also shoved the National Football League toward acceptance of the plain facts that professional football is large-scale business and that its employees have rights even if they are athletes.

BARNSBORO, Jan. 2 (UPI) A Stafford Township man armed with a revolver abducted a woman he once apparently had dated, but the man was seized eight and a half hours later and the woman released unharmed, the police said.

WASINGTON, Jan. 2 The United States is approaching the point at which, statistically, all of its legitimate babies will be wanted at birth by their parents, according to an analytical study of national data published today.

LUSAKA, Zambia Zambia's President Kenneth Kaunda has impeccable credentials as a third-world statesman and nobody can complain he is insufficiently opposed to that contemporary bogeyman, the United States. A member of his Central Committee, equivalent to a "politburo" in Mr. Kaunda's one-party system, recently spoke out against American "imperialism" in Havana.

Susanne C. Mayer, daughter of Mrs. Robert Mayer of Ludwigsburg, West Germany, and the late Mr. Mayer, was married in Sharon, Conn., yesterday morning to Otto A. Kaletsch, president of Panta Inc., a corporate planning and management services company here. Justice of the Peace Joan Blanchet performed the ceremony in the Sharon Town Hall.
Robert E. McGinnis, a solo clarinetist with leading symphony orchestras, died of a heart attack Thursday at Syosset (L.I.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Huntington. L.I.

Zdenek Macal, a Czechoslovak conductor who was a winner of the 1966 Mitropoulos Conducting Competition here, is making his New York Philharmonic debut in the orchestra's concerts at Avery Fisher Hall this weekend, Mr. Macal, who is in his late 30's was appointed music director of the Cologne Radio Symphony Orchestra in 1970 after having been principal conductor of the Prague Symphony for several years.

Eight more restaurants have been cited by the city Health Department for failing a Health Code inspection. They have been warned they are subject to being closed if violations are not corrected before a second inspection.

John Maye, head of the Transit Authority Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday called for the restoring of 500 transit police jobs to bring the force back to its level of 3,600 before the attrition and layoffs of last summer.
Buying by commercial firms, apparently to fill some recent orders by Korea and Peru, helped increase wheat futures, prices yesterday enough to keep them unchanged or a penny a bushel higher.

LISBON, Jan. 2 Public demonstrations outside prisons were banned today in the northern city of Oporto after incidents last night during which three persons were shot dead and four gravely wounded by guards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 The International Monetary Fund disclosed today that it had extended more balance-of-payments assistance to its member countries in 1975 than in any other year of the Fund's 30year history.

The towaway fee for illegally parked cars in Manhattan will go up from $50 to $65 starting Monday, The fee is in addition to the customary $25 fine for illegal parking and $5 a day for storage of the impounded car.

Misfit hands regularly present problems in bidding, play and defense. If a partnership with a misfit has the high-card values for game, it will usually attempt three notrump, but the problems involved in trying to make nine tricks are often insoluble.

With the stock market embarked upon the uncertain course of another new year, the ranks of Wall Street analysts are filled with optimists, pessimists and others who simply are hedging their forecasts.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (UPI) The remaining crewmen of the strike-stalled cargo ship, M.S. Niuta, under orders from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to leave the country as soon as possible, spent today ashore awaiting transportation back to Israel.

Mrs. George Beutner of Bettendorf, Iowa., Francis J. O'Connor of Buffalo, N.Y., and Julie Swain of Seattle, Wash., have finally learned that they won $2,000 in a contest, but 13 other winners are still unfound.

The marriage of Anne Tolstoi Foster, a vice president of Cunningham Walsh Inc., the advertising agency, to Judge Richard Wingard Wallach of the Civil Court of New York took place here yesterday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Budd Goodman performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Edward Tolstoi, father of the bride.

The Village Gate, the Greenwich Village night club that has had its share of legal tangles, lately, was closed by the police last night on the basis of an order issued by the city's Department of Buildings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Eastern Airlines has proposed a six-month program of monthly increases in domestic passenger fares starting with a 1 percent increase on February 1.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Brazil rescinded its ban on the Capetown-toRio yacht race tonight and announced it would allow entry to its ports.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Jan. 2 To the sustained applause of their supporters, Suffolk Democrats today formally took control of the County Legislature for the first time in this traditionally Republican county. But before the applause had subsided, their G.O.P, rivals engaged them in a spirited confrontation over minor technical matters.

TRENTON, Jan. 2 A study by the state's Department of Labor and Industry says New Jersey's big glass industry is suffering from a "substantial" disadvantage in competing with other states in the region because of higher fuel costs and more stringent air-pollution standards.

The Chemical Bank of New York confirmed yesterday that it had signed a consent agreement covering refunds for fees charged to a total of 2,500 customers whose bank accounts had been subjected to legal actions by others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 President Ford is expected to name soon a full-time political operative to link the White House and his campaign committee to remedy what a committee official said today was inadequate attention to politics at the White House.
NEW DELHI, Saturday, Jan. 3 The Indian Government has succeeded in gaining indirect control of India's largest newspaper chain, according to reliable sources here.

Chessie System, Inc., which owns the Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio as well as a number of affiliated railroads, reported yesterday a 135 percent gain in its fourthquarter earnings. Last January, the Massachusetts Department of Social Services reported "an alarming increase" of child-abuse cases during 1974 and predicted that they would keep on rising, By June, Jack Hagenbuch, the department's coordinator of protective services, was saying that cases had nearly tripled. "In 1974 we were averaging 58 cases per month. This year it is more like 154, and still increasing."

Wheat, corn and soybean prices rose sharply yesterday in the first full post-holiday session of the new year, following a slow session last Friday as many traders took a fourday weekend.

Saying "my love for the game is gone," Joe Bugner announced yesterday his retirement from boxing at the age of 25. Millard Fillmore, 13th in the line of Presidents and last in the memory of his countrymen, drew a record commemorative throng to his grave in Buffalo yesterday 30 people.

Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, said here today.

Kazuyoshi Akiyama, the 31-year-old Japanese conductor who has been active in this city as conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, faced the New York Philharmonic for the first time last night. The National Book Critics Circle, a two-year-old organization of 300 professional book reviewers and book editors, announced yesterday its first annual awards for books written by Americans and published in 1975.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 11--"It was easy, we were in control all the way,"'said Bill Melchionni with a winning smile in his locker stall today after the Nets breezed to a 112-102 victory over the Indiana Pacers before a crowd of 4,935--the second smallest of the season--at Nassau Coliseum.
Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the State Health Commissioner recently suggested that 1975 be called the Year of the Investigations and 1976 the Year of the Budget.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 11 (AP)--Nigerian demonstrators protesting United States policy toward Angola broke into the grounds of the United States Embassy today, plastered slogans on windows and threw sticks and stones at the building. No injuries were reported.

Joseph C. Woodcock Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor, said yesterday that he would ask New Jersey medical officials to consider suspending the license of Dr. X, pending the outcome of Mr. Woodcock's renewed inquiry into suspicious deaths at Riverdell Hospital in 1966.
Many of the discounts now being offered in this postholiday sales season are not always bargains: In some instances, merchandise may have been marked up just before being marked down, ...

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, and District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx failed to agree yesterday on the text of a proposed executive order that would clarify the authority of Mr. Nadjari to investigate the sale of judgeships and political jobs in the Bronx.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 11 (AP) --Chris Evert defeated Evonne Goolagong, 6-3, 7-6 today for the $50,000 first prize in the L'eggs World Series of Women's Tennis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--A nearly completed inquiry into possible financial mismanagement within the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reportedly focused on John P. Mohr, the bureau's retired administrative chief, who was for years one of the F.B.I.'s most powerful, if little-known, executives.
A lot of charm can go a long way. So proved Carla Fracci, partnered by Ted Kivitt, in American Ballet Theater's "Coppelia" on Saturday afternoon at the Uris Theater.

ALBANY, Jan. 11--The State Assembly is expected to take up a conflict-of-interest bill this week that would require members of the powerful Public Service Commission to disclose any financial interest they might have in any utility under their control.
QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 11 (Reuters)--The commanders of Ecuador's three armed services took over the Government today in a peaceful coup in which President Guillermo Rodriguez Lara resinged.
Motown Records, the soul music label now based in Los Angeles, is fond of presenting its corporate image as "a family."

The use of a new test to measure achievement in reading here has resulted in surprisingly high scores by pupils, but city school authorities cautioned against interpreting the scores to mean that there had been "a massive improvement" in pupil reading.

Eight neighborhood branch libraries--three in Manhattan, three in the Bronx and two on Staten Island--will be closed Saturday, the first to be shut in the city because of budget cuts, when the New York Public Library lays off 118 more emoloyees.
TRENTON, Jan. 11--Governor Byrne did not have to labor long preparing his address for the opening session of the 197th New Jersey Legislature, which convenes on Tuesday.

JERUSALEM, Jan, 12 A group of Israeli doves, including two members of Parliament, a former major general and a number of writers and scholars, today called on the Government to open negotiations with "a recognized and authoritative body of the Palestinian Arab people."
Mayor Beame yesterday accepted the resignation of Michael J. Lazar as Transportation Administrator after weeks of rumors that a shake-up in the agency was pending.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 13 Foreign Minister Andrel A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union publicly urged the Japanese today to avoid lining up politically with China against the Soviet Union.
Six rare sea animals that resemble giant versions of the sow bugs found under rocks and rotting wood were placed on display at the New York Aquarium yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 The Security Council opened its debate on the Middle East today by voting overwhelmingly to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate with the rights of a United Nations member nation despite a vehement objection by the United States that such action "eroded the influence and authority" of the Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Turning down pleas from school authorities and from a group representing Chicanos, the Supreme Court refused today to take a second look at segregation in the public schools of Denver-rsegregation that the Court discussed in a landmark ruling in 1973.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that major portions of New York State's fair campaign practices plan including portions that forbid a candidate to make racial attacks on another candidate or to misrepresent an opponent's qualifications deliberately are unconstitutional under the First Amendment.

In the Philippines's 35-25 victory over China, the 10man Chinese team lost each of the six-round matches by an average of 1 2/3 points. Moreover, the Chinese fought Round 4, played in Shanghai, to a 5-5 standoff.

MELVILLE, L.I., Jan. 12 Responding to reports that a 4-year-old boy was severely beaten at a psychiatric facility here last week, state and Suffolk County agencies today began a formal investigation of the alleged incident.

Ralph Howard Peterson, a World War II correspondent for the National Broadcasting Company who since 1948 had directed Washington television news shows for the network, died of cancer Sunday in Washington. He was 60 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

The nation's steel production for the first full week of 1976 ran 7.3 percent higher than in the week ended Jan. 3 but, for the first 10 days of 1976, it trailed the year-ago level by 17.2 percent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Adirondack Park Agency has now surmounted the second of three judicial hurdles that have confronted it from the very beginning of its pioneer attempt at landuse planning. Its first success came in a State Supreme Court decision affirming the agency's right to withhold a budding permit on scenic and esthetic grounds.
HONG KONG, Jan. 12 Although the last American PX in Vietnam was closed in April, the impact of its bounty is still being felt but now in North Vietnam.

The Health Department has cited 14 more food establishments as violators of the Health Code. In setting final inspections for them, the department also released the results of final inspections at 22 previously cited places, including six that were closed because of failure to correct violations. MOSCOW, Jan. 12 A Russian play based on Kurt Vonnegut Jr.'s novel "Slaughterhouse-Five" has opened in Moscow, and it proved to be an exercise in converting the literature of the absurd into the theater of realism.
TRENTON, Jan. 12 Four of the five blacks in the State Assembly, all Democrats, say they plan to form a voting bloc in the 1976 Legislature, which opens tomormow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12? Lawyers for the WashingtonBaltimore Newspaper Guild and for several hundred Washington Post guildsmen who face union disciplinary charges reached an out-of-court agreement today to delay union trial board proceedings until after Jan. 27.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court ruling that price fixing practices, which would be illegal in other industries, may be acceptable for the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12? The Federal Government said today in its first comprehensive report on the state of health of Americans that the population was generally healthy but the American life style continued to be a major health hazard.

It affirmed without comment a lower court ruling that struck down some of the major provisions of New York's fair campaign code provisions that prohibited certain types of statements, such as attacks based on race by candidates in political campaigns.

Three pipe bombs were found packed in a paper bag in an underground passageway next to the United Nations headquarters on 42d Street east of First Avenue yesterday. The police and United Nations officials said one had been timed to explode at 3 P.M., which would have been a half hour before the scheduled start of the expected stormy Middle East debate in the Security Council.

Dame Agatha Christie, the English writer who created two of the most distinctive sleuths of detective fiction Jane Marple and Hercole Poirot as the central characters in a hugely successful series of mystery stories for half a century, died yesterday at her home in Wallingford, England, 47 miles west of London. She was 85 years old.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 Common Pleas Court Judge Donald E. Ziegler today fined the striking Pittsburgh Federation of Teachers $25,000 for failing to comply with a back-to-work order.

Dame Agatha Christie, creator of two of the most distinctive sleuths of detective fiction Jane Marple and Hercule Poirot and a hugely successful writer of mysteries for half a century, died yesterday at her home in Wallingford, 47 miles west of London. She was 85 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 12 (UPI) Strikes were reported today in a part of central Angola held by nationalist forces that are supported by the Soviet Union. The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola said in a broadcast from Luanda, its capital, that walkouts by teachers, electricians, bakers, nurses, mechanics and civil servants had almost paralyzed essential services in the town of Quibala and surrounding districts.

"Nova," the public-TV science series produced at Boston station WGBH, has returned for a new season and is being presented by WNET/ 13 on Tuesdays at 8 P.M. Once again, the programs constitute a collection of original domestic efforts and acquisitions from Britain. So far, with last week's American "Predictable Disaster" and tonight's British "Joey," the overseas contingent is far ahead on points.

LES DIABLERETS, Switzerland, Jan. 12 (AP) LiseMarie Morerod of SwitZerland won a women's World Cup special slalom ski race here today while at nearby Adelboder dense fog postponed the second run of a men's giant slalom race. Gustavo Thoeni of Italy leads after the first run.

FELINE FIESTA Who's for cats? The Museum of American Folk Art at 49 West 53d Street, with a new exhibition today through March 26, Some diligent museum digging on the subject has unearthed the fact that the cat figures more prominently in American folk art than perhaps any other animal cats on quilts, hooked rugs, furniture, fireboards, pottery, samplers, canes, even on a scrimshaw tooth.

While spokesmen for the Palestine Liberation Organization are seizing the spotlight at the United Nations Security Council, armed units of the P.L.O. are actively engaged in a vicious power struggle inside the Arab world. The unfolding tragedy in Lebanon may be far more decisive for the future of the P.L.O. than the verbal exercises along the East River.

Panels accumulated and chairman delayed, audiences moved trom the 92d Street Y.M. and Y.W.H A. to the Park Avenue Synagogue to the Jewish Museum and finally yesterday the three-day conference on Jewish Cultural Arts ended.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Jan. 12 (AP) Ronald Reagan said today "I guess I made a mistake" in the presentation of his proposal to transfer certain Federal programs and their funds to state and local governments.
Roy Wilkins announced yesterday that he would resign as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Jan. 1. 1977.

The season's greeting card was an attractive woodcut, the work of Maxwell B. Roberts, a New York artist who had depicted a scene in the Dutch fishing village of Spakenburg. Mr. Roberts sent a print on behalf of his wife. Rhoda, and himself with a check for $100 to the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Suggesting the imminent invention of a proverb warning against Frenchmen "bearing gifts," an $800,000 son et lumiere (sound and light spectacle) to be installed at George Washington's Mount Vernon home heads a $4 million list of 200th-birthday presents to be offered the United States by its oldest ally.

A.A. Sommer Jr., who was passed over for appointment as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has let it be known that he will not accept reappointment when his term as a member expires in June.

Representatives of the Senate Intelligence Committee, the Ford Administration and the so-called "intelligence community" have started joint discussions on what, if any, reforms are needed in that community. Unfortunately, the most far-reaching proposal the prohibition of covert operations abroad appears to have been rejected in advance.

PARIS, Jan. 12 Minos Colocotronis, a Greek shipowner forced into financial difficulties by the depressed world tanker market, announced today he had worked out an arrangement with his principal bankers to permit continued operation.
Bruce Norman, a radio announcer and singer in the 1930's died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

Manalapan Township, N.J., Jan. 12 The police today found three surviving relatives of the 77-year-old elementary school teacher who was found frozen to death last Saturday in her unheated home although she had more than $135,000 on deposit in area banks.

The Rev. John T. Nelson associate dean of the Staten Island campus of St. John's University, died Sunday of a heart attack in the residence of the Vincentian order, of which he was a member, at the Queens campus of the university. He was 50 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 A price increase on Ford Motor Company cars that took effect a week ago was much larger than the increase in costs that has taken place since the introduction of the 1976 models, the staff of the Council on Wage and Price Stability reported today.

Bank stocks sold off sharply yesterday and then recovered most of their losses in the wake of weekend reports that the First National City Bank and the Chase Manhattan Bank were on a "problem list" compiled by the Comptroller of the Currency.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Atlantic Richfield Company and the Pacific Lighting Corporation terminated an agreement today under which natural gas consumers in southern California were paying in advance for rights to Alaskan gas.

Louis E. Walker, who played a key role in the financial marketplace as publisher of The Sheets, the daily quotation tables for over-the-counter stocks and bonds, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and had lived in Bermuda and at 535 East 86th Street since selling the National Quotation Bureau at the end of 1963 to Commerce Clearing House Inc.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 12 (AP) Iceland told the North Atlantic Council today that if the British Navy did not leave Icelandic waters, that Iceland would reconsider its place in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 12 An association representing 25 nursing homes on Long Island said today that it would not accept any more patients and would ask the State Health Department to remove its patients because of an impending strike by employees at the homes.

DENVER, Jan. 12 (UPI) Byron Beck, a reserve player, led a third-quarter rally and David Thompson scored 14 of his 32 points in the fourth period tonight to give Denver a 139-122 victory over the San Antonio Spurs, in the American Basketball Association.
Harvey A. Peltz, president of Getman Judd, lumber dealers of Wilton, Conn., died Sunday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 48 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

Britain lost the American Revolutionary War for a combination of reasons with striking similarities to the American experience in Vietnam, according to an analysis by the specialist in military history at the United States Military Academy in West Point.
PARIS, Jan. 12 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing replaced several Cabinet-level officials today but retained the major figures of his administration.

Last year, coincidentally, two choreographers of international repute were drawn to do versions of "Daphnis and Chloe," neither one of which captured its special spirit. Stock prices shrugged off early profit taking yesterday to resume their climb in heavy trading and to extend one of the biggest sustained advances in Wall Street history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) Third-party political candidates can demand equal time from radio and television stations, even if they have not qualified for a state ballot, merely by declaring an intention to run as a write-in candidate, a Federal appellate court has ruled.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Jan. 12 Senator Henry Jackson, in his first full week of allout campaigning for the Democratrc Presidential nomination, seems to have indelibly charted his course for the next three months.
A 72-year-old retired electrical engineer, Joseph Worth, said he had been a regular visitor of the Van Cortlandt Branch of the New York Public Library for 10 years, calling it his "second home."

The average rate on threemontn Treasury bills dropped to 4.83 percent yesterday afternoon as the Government sold $3 billion of these short-term securities at its weekly sale.

QUITO, Ecuador, Jan. 12 (AP) Ecuador's new military rulers sought today to form a predominantly military Cabinet, promising greater civilian participation later, but the nation's fragmented political parties demanded immediate elections.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Tuesday, Jan. 13 The heads of state of the 46 members of the Organization of African Unity remained divided early today, but appeared to be seeking a compromise that would defer any definitive action on the Angolan civil war.

Thirty-ffve women, part of a neighborhood group that has been occupying a closed firehouse in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn since last Thanksgiving Eve, have begun receiving instruction in how to fight fires.

A recalculation by the Greater New York Bridge Association has changed the result of the 1975 New York player-of-the-year contest. The winner, subject to official confirmation, was Matt Granovetter of New York, and not, as previously reported, Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J.

The turbulence that attended the early weeks of California's admirable new farm labor law is giving way to a much more orderly application of the processes of industrial democracy. Commissioner Dave DeBusschere of the American Basketball Association yesterday ordered the final 19 minutes 5 seconds of the New York Nets' chaotic loss to the Virginia Squires last week replayed from the point of an error by officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Commerce Department estimates that the volume of total economic output this year will rise by 6 or 7 percent on the basis of a continued growth in production by United States industry.

Two Family Court probation officers, two court clerks and an elevator operator were honored yesterday for their contribution to the city's Family Court by judges and lawyers who have worked with them.

Gen. Guillermo Rodriguez Lara has been removed as President of Ecuador by peaceful military coup in the same way that Gen. William Wikoff Smith, chairman of Kewanee Industries and former president of the Kewanee Oil Company, now a subsidiary, founded in 1871 by his great-grandfather, died Sunday of heart disease in Lankenau Hospital, Overbrook, Pa. He was 56 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Norman's Cay, a Bahamas islet he bought in 1964.

The Formica Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to increase its price for melamine component panels with particleboard core by 10.5 percent, effective Jan. 26. This would average 4 cents a square foot.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Federal Government said today in its first comprehensive report on the state of health of Americans that the population was generally healthy but the American life style continued to be a major health hazard.

The city and Nassau and Suffolk Counties plan to require supermarkets and other grocery outlets to continue marking each item's price on its package.

LONDON, Jan. 12 The British Government announced plans tonight to bring together Roman Catholic and Protestant politicians of Northern Ireland in another attempt to work out a political settlement for the province.

A recalculation by the Greater New York Bridge Association has changed the result of the 1975 New York player-of-the-year contest. The winner, subject to official confirmation, was Matt Granovetter of New York, and not, as previously reported, Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J.

Skid row is not precisely a fun place to spend an evening even if you are just watching rather than skidding. However, this is what "Alley Cats," a new play about a drunk called Larry and a toy doll called Ginger, is all about. It opened last night at the Wood Theater, which must be one of the smallest theaters in Manhattan. It is not just a storefront theater it is a tiny storefront theater.

PARIS The Lebanese civil war is as pointless as it is dangerous. No internal faction within Lebanon's complex society and no external nation in the jittery Middle East stands to gain anything from the bloody, drawn-out, destructive battle. The Citizens Budget Commission estimated yesterday that the city's real-estate tax could jump about 51 cents to $8.70 for each $100 of assessed valuation for the fiscal year beginning July 1 if the city used its full taxing power.

Rutgers squeezed an inexperienced Columbia basketball team between a pesky full-court press and an explosive offense last night at Levien Gym on Morningside Heights and won its 12th game without defeat, 94-65.

When Sekou Toure's Guinea in 1958 became the only one of France's African colonies to reject General de Gaulle's offer of a French "community" of African states choosing full independence instead the French leader reacted in anger. He ordered all French administrators, teachers, doctors and technicians out of Guinea. Before leaving, they destroyed documents, ripped out telephones, smashed light bulbs and stripped the police of uniforms and weapons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Democratic national chairman and the chairman of the Federal Election Commission, a Republican, today criticized what they said was the attempt by the White House to designate the Cabinet-level appointment of Rogers C.B. Morton as a governmenttal assignment rather than a political one.
Mrs. Phillip Hoffmann's Stick to Beauty pulled clear in the stretch and won the third running of the $38,425 Busanda Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.
LES GETS, France, Jan. 14 (UPI) Danielle Debernard of France, mastering ice and slush, ended her three-year losing streak today when she won a women's World Cup slalom race.
PARIS, Jan. 14 Baron Guy de Rothschild said today that he was "more amused than shocked" over the initially unfriendly American reaction to his take-over of the Copperweld Corporation of Pittsburgh.
RIVERTON, Jan. 14 (AP) A policeman was shot to death and another wounded today after they disarmed and tried to handcuff a former mental patient, the police said.

LENS LINE UP The midtown Kodak Photo Gallery, 43d Street and Avenue of the Americas, has just opened its latest free exhibition, a threepart display called "A Portrait of the Nation," running through March 13 in a picture series with a Bicentennial theme.

And, above all, there was Sarah Caldwell in the pit.

Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, was indicted yesterday with six of his associates on Federal charges of conspiracy to misappropriate more than $100 million in assets of mutual funds managed by I.O.S. Limited.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala Hundreds of years ago, when the Maya Indians ruled northern Central America, the priests and nobles adorned themselves with some of the finest carved jade in the world.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 Cancer deaths occur in New Jersey at a higher rate than in any other state in the country, a report by the Cancer Institute of New Jersey said today.

Ernest S. Starkman, vice president in charge of the environmental activities staff of the General Motors Corporation, died, apparently of a heart attack, Tuesday evening at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 56 years old.

Greta Rauch Goldman, publicity director for many famous musicians, died at Gracie Square Hospital on Tuesday after a long illness resulting from burns suffered at her home, 240 Central Park South. She was 74 years old.

She tried to get an ophthalmologist to treat her, and then another. Both refused.

The Board of Education yesterday asked Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, for a new hearing on his recent orders calling for the integration of three heavily black city schools next fall.

KINSHASA, Zaire. Jan. 16 Holden Roberto, president of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, angrily denied tonight an .American assessment that his movement was approaching the point of collapse:

Robert E. Hampton, chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission, who earlier this week said he saw no conflict of interest in accepting the free use of a hunting lodge leased by Rockwell International because his agency did no business with Rockwell, corrected himself yesterday. He said his agency had, in fact, given Rockwell a $74,000 contract in 1974.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 Curfews and growing tension among the players cropped up today as definite signs that the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Dallas Cowboys were about to play the next-to-last game of the football season.

Grain and soybean futures prices held steady yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, despite the expectation of some there that prices might close sharply higher. They reasoned that the crop report showing the corn supply at a record total of 5.77 billion bushels instead of the previous estimate of 5.8 billion would lead to a spate of new buying.
Golf honored Jack Nicklaus, Patty Berg and Gary Player yesterday. Nicklaus was named the player of the year for 1975 by the Professional Golfers' Association and the Golf Writers Association.
